attributes.title: Auto-associative strengthening of features in working memory

summary.value:
See https://osf.io/p2g3d/ for PDF version, including task figure. 

Working memory (WM) is the ability to hold information in mind momentarily and use it flexibly for future decision-making1. WM flexibility allows humans to select and prioritize information depending on its current relevance2 and to hold novel items in mind by combining arbitrary features into coherent representations (“feature binding”)3,4. In this study, we will use behavioural measures, electroencephalography (EEG) and eye-tracking to investigate whether selecting one feature of a multi-feature item in WM automatically privileges associated item features, as predicted by recent computational models of WM flexibility5,6.

According to recent models of WM flexibility, features in WM are retrieved through pattern completion, perhaps via strengthened connectivity between features belonging to the same objects5,6. If so, a retrieval cue that directs attention to one item-feature in memory should automatically privilege all features of the same object, even if these are not currently relevant. To test this prediction, we present participants with two oriented, coloured bars on each trial. After a delay, a probe prompts them to report the orientation angle of one of the remembered items. During the delay, participants are additionally presented with a non-predictive retro-cue (i.e. ‘incidental’ cueing7,8) and asked to make a speeded response if the cued colour did not match the colour of either of the remembered items. On congruent trials, the item that was incidentally cued is also probed during memory recall; on incongruent trials, the other item is probed.

Previous studies have shown that selecting information in WM is associated with faster and more accurate behavioural performance9–11 and improved neural decoding of relevant features from fMRI and EEG12–15. Here we will test if this is similarly true for object-features that are not currently relevant. First, if selecting the cued colour for the incidental task automatically privileges associated, but currently redundant item-features, orientation judgements should be faster and more precise on congruent than on incongruent trials. This would replicate previous behavioural findings8. Alternatively, it may be possible to selectively attend the cued colour without associated benefits to orientation judgements for the same item. If so, there should be no difference in performance between congruent and incongruent trials.

Second, using alpha lateralization and gaze bias as indices of spatial attention in WM16,17, we will test if spatial attention is directed toward the original position of the cued item following the non-predictive colour cue, despite location being a fully redundant feature in this task. If so, we expect contralateral minus ipsilateral alpha power to be reduced relative to the original location of the cued item. We also expect gaze position to be biased toward the cued item’s original position. Alternatively, there may be no significant alpha lateralization or gaze bias relative to the cued item’s original location, which would suggest a mechanism for colour retrieval in WM without involvement of spatial attention.

Finally, if selecting the incidentally cued colour by extension strengthens the representation of the orientation of the cued item, neural decodability should improve for the cued item’s orientation relative to the orientation of the uncued item following the cue, even though the item’s orientation is irrelevant to the ‘incidental’ change-detection judgement. Alternatively, it may be possible to selectively access a single feature in memory, similar to selective coding for only relevant item features observed during encoding18,19. We expect the orientation of the cued item to be decodable from EEG activity patterns following incidental cue onset and decoding accuracy to be greater for the cued than the uncued item. Alternatively, patterns of activity in the EEG channels may contain no information about the cued item and/or may contain equal information about the orientations of both items following the incidental cue.

At the time of writing, data collection for this study is ongoing but the data have not yet been analysed. 

Methods

Participants
We plan to recruit a total of 35 participants (see below for power calculations). Participants must be aged 18-40 years old, have normal or corrected-to-normal vision (including normal colour vision), and not have any history of neurological or neuropsychiatric disorders. Participants provide informed consent prior to participating in the study. They are reimbursed for their time at a rate of £15/hour or with course credit. The study has been approved by the Oxford Central University Research Ethics Committee (R55073/RE008). 


 
Figure 1. Task design. Participants remember two oriented, coloured bars on each trial. During the delay, they are presented with a non-predictive colour cue that asks them to make a speeded mismatch-response (i.e., does it differ from the colours in memory?; ‘incidental task’). At the end of the trial, they report the orientation of one of the items, cued by colour. This item may be the same as was also cued on the incidental task (congruent condition, 50%), or the other item (incongruent condition, 50%).

Procedure
Participants perform a computerised experimental task (see Figure 1 for task design). It consists of a continuous report WM task, in which participants report the orientation angle of one of two items in memory at the end of a delay. During the delay, participants perform a dual “incidental task”, where a non-predictive colour cue, presented centrally, requires a speeded mismatch response: does the colour differ from the colours of the two memory items. At the end of the trial, a probe indicates which of the two items participants should report. This can either be the same item as the one that was cued on the incidental task (congruent condition, 50% of trials) or the other item in memory (incongruent condition, 50% of trials). 

Following an initial fixation period of 300 ms, participants are presented with a WM display consisting of two oriented, coloured bars. The WM items are presented on screen for 250 ms followed by a delay period of 750 ms. For the incidental task, participants are presented with a colour cue for 200 ms. On mismatch trials (20 %), participants press the space bar within 1000 ms of incidental cue onset, after which the rest of the trial is skipped. Participants receive feedback for correct or incorrect responses. On match trials (80 %), participants make no response and the trial continues (unless they accidentally press the space bar, in which case the trial is also discontinued). After another delay of 500 ms, the probe appears on the screen. The colour of the probe indicates which of the two items participants should report. Participants use the arrow keys to turn the on-screen dial to match the orientation of the probed item and press the space bar to respond. There is no maximum time to respond, but once participants initiate a response the trial will time-out 2500 ms after response initiation. They receive visual feedback of the correct orientation for 100 ms. The inter-trial-interval is jittered between 400-800 ms. At the end of each block, they receive feedback of their incidental colour change-detection rate and on their mean absolute error.

Participants complete a total of 1400 trials. The 20% non-match incidental trials are excluded, leaving 1120 trials per participant for analyses. Participants practice the task beforehand until they reach a criterion of >80% correct incidental task change-detection rate and <25 degrees mean absolute error relative to the target orientation. 

Apparatus and stimuli
The task is programmed and stimuli presented in Matlab with Psychtoolbox20,21.  The task is presented on a 24 inch, 1920x1080 pixel monitor running at 100 Hz.

Stimuli are presented on a grey background (RGB = 0.5, 0.5, 0.5). A fixation target is presented at the centre of the screen throughout the trial. It consists of a filled black circle (0.5° diameter) with a white cross inside (width: 0.15°). To signal trial onset and to encourage fixation, a black dot (0.15° diameter) appears inside the fixation target 300 ms before the onset of the memory array. The memory array consists of two oriented, coloured bars inside circles (diameter: 6°, width: 0.3°). The colours are picked at random without replacement out of four possible colours on each trial: red (RGB: 153, 0, 27), purple (122, 39, 150), green (16, 83, 0), and blue (0, 72, 136), chosen to be isoluminant in CieLab space. On every trial, the orientation of each stimulus is randomly selected without replacement from a uniform distribution of 160 orientation angles between 1.1250 and 180 degrees. The two WM items are presented laterally 6° from the fixation target. For the incidental task, participants are presented with a colour cue appearing around the fixation target (diameter: 1°, width: 0.5°). The probe is a tilted bar inside a circle (6°; same size as memory items) and matches the colour of the probed memory item. The orientation angle of the probe is selected at random on each trial between 1 and 180 degrees. The probe is presented 6° above or below the fixation target, with equal probability, pseudorandomised for the full experimental session. This type of probe display has been reported to reduce the risk of stimulus-specific eye-movements22. Feedback of the correct target orientation is presented as a white line on top of their reported orientation for comparison.

EEG data acquisition
Electroencephalography (EEG) is recorded at a sampling rate of 1kHz using Synamps amplifiers (Neuroscan, Inc., Albany, CA) and Curry Neuroimaging Suite (v7.0.12 X) software. Sixty-one electrodes are positioned according to the 10-10 system23. Eye movements are recorded from bipolar EOG derivations from electrodes above and below the right eye (vertical) and lateral to each eye (horizontal). A ground electrode is placed on the left elbow and the left mastoid is used as the active reference. 

In addition, we record participants’ eye movements using an eye tracking camera (EyeLink) tracking at least one eye at a rate of 1kHz.

Analyses

Behavior
Our behavioural measures of interest are mean absolute error from the target angle and median response initiation times (henceforth RT).  We will perform paired samples t-tests (one-tailed) to test for a main effect of congruency for both measures. We predict that mean absolute error and median RTs will be significantly lower for congruent relative to incongruent trials. 

To explore the sources of errors, we will also fit a swap model to the data24. The model is an extension of the Zhang & Luck (2008)25 model and estimates the precision, target rate, non-target rate and guess rate of responses. As above, we will perform paired samples t-tests (two-tailed) for each measure to test for a main effect of congruency. 

Preprocessing of eye-movement data 
The EyeLink EDF file is converted to ASCII format and read into Matlab using the Fieldtrip toolbox26. The data is epoched around the onset of the WM array (-1 to 4 seconds). We will take the mean of the right and the left eye and downsample the data to 500 Hz. Eye-blinks will be detected (zeros in the eye-position data) and interpolated from -100 to +100 ms around the blink onset and offset using linear interpolation.

EEG Preprocessing
Preprocessing of the EEG data will be performed in Matlab using the Fieldtrip toolbox26. The ERPs are re-referenced offline to the mean of the right and left mastoid and down-sampled to 500 Hz. We will apply a high-pass filter of 0.1 Hz and a low-pass filter of 40 Hz to all channels.  The data will be epoched around the onset of the WM array (-1 to 4 seconds). We will perform ICA to remove any heartbeat artefacts and/or artefacts due to eye-blinks. Artefact rejection will be performed separately for the time-window following WM array onset (0-1 s) and the cue onset (1-2.5 s). We will mark epochs with a high degree of variance using the Fieldtrip summary plot for visual artefact rejection and further mark epochs that exceed a cut-off threshold of 50 of the z-transformed value of the pre-processed data to detect any large artefacts due to muscle movements. We will further exclude epochs with saccades identified from the eye-tracking data. In case eye-tracking data is missing, we will visually inspect EOGs to reject saccade epochs.

We will exclude participants with fewer than 80% of epochs remaining following artefact rejection from further analyses. We expect to reject about 5% of trials on average per participant, based on the experiment used for computing our power analyses27.

Time frequency decomposition and alpha lateralization
To test whether a centrally presented, non-predictive colour cue draws spatial attention to the original position of the cued item, we will compute the alpha lateralization index relative to the cued item in the time window after incidental cue onset (1.2–1.8 s; to avoid carry over from probe onset). Spectral decomposition of the data will be performed in Matlab with the FieldTrip toolbox26. We will apply Hanning tapers with a time window width of five cycles per frequency, with frequencies of interest between 8 Hz and 14 Hz in steps of 1 Hz. We will log-transform the power at each frequency (10*log10) and calculate the mean power over contralateral and ipsilateral posterior channels (P8/7, P6/5, P4/3, PO8/7, PO4/3, O2/1) relative to the cued and uncued item. To get a lateralization index we will take the difference between contralateral and ipsilateral alpha power averaged over the specified time-window and test for significant lateralization using a one-sample t-test (one-tailed, >0).

Gaze bias analysis
A recent study has shown that human gaze may be biased toward attended spatial locations in WM17. Here, we will similarly use gaze bias as an index of spatial attention towards the original position of the cued item. If spatial attention is drawn to the original position of the incidentally cued item, we expect horizontal gaze position to be biased toward the left (i.e. negative values) for left cue trials and toward the right (i.e. positive values) for right cue trials. First, we will centre the data to the mean position during fixation (300–100 ms before stimulus onset). We will then normalize the data according to the eccentricity of the memory items, so +/-100% corresponds to the eyes being focused on the original position of the memory items (e.g. 6 dva) and 0% corresponds to fixation. We will plot the horizontal gaze position following incidental cue onset separately for left and right cue trials. To obtain an aggregate measure of ‘towardness’17, we will take the mean gaze position for right cue trials minus the mean gaze position for left cue trials, divided by two, averaged across the time-window following incidental cue onset (1.2–1.8). We will test for significant gaze bias toward the cued item (i.e. ‘towardness’) using a one-sample t-test (one-tailed, >0). 

Orientation decoding
To test whether the patterns of activity in the EEG channels contain information about the orientation angles of the items in memory, we will use Mahalanobis distance to calculate the trial-wise distances between the multidimensional activity at each time point for each of the 160 possible orientation angles in memory, grouped into 16 angle bins distributed around a 180 degree angle space. The left and right memory items will be decoded separately and independently for each participant. As in Wolff et al. (2017), we will perform the analyses on the 17 posterior channels (P7, P5, P3, P1, Pz, P2, P4, P6, P8, PO7, PO3, POz, PO4, PO8, O1, Oz and O2). 

The decoding procedure will follow an 8-fold cross-validation approach to calculate the decoding accuracy of the orientation of interest for each trial. The activity pattern of the trials of the testing fold at a particular time-point will be compared to the trials of k-1 training folds. The trials of the training folds are averaged into 16 orientation bins relative to the test trial orientation, each bin containing trials with orientations within a range of 11.25° (variable bins, see below). As we expect to exclude trials due to artefacts, we will ensure equal trial-numbers in each bin by random subsampling. We will compute the pairwise Mahalanobis distances between the test trials and each of the orientation bins using the covariance matrix estimated from trials in the k-1 training folds, using a shrinkage estimator28. To obtain a visual representation of a tuning curve, the 16 distances will be ordered as a function of orientation difference, mean-centered, and sign-reversed, so higher values represent greater similarity between the test trial and the training set. This will be repeated for all train and test fold combinations. To obtain reliable estimates, the above procedure will be repeated 100 times (with random folds each time), separately for two orientation spaces (bin centres: 5.625° to 174.015° and 11.25° to 180°, each in steps of 11.25°), and averaged across the resulting 200 samples for each of the 16 Mahalanobis distance values at each time-point.

Finally, to obtain a summary measure of decoding accuracy, we will compute the cosine-weighted means of the tuning curves12,27, and compute the mean of the resulting 16 values. Higher values will reflect greater orientation tuning and thereby greater decoding accuracy for that trial. We will take the mean over trials, resulting in a single decoding value for each time-point for each participant.

To test for significant orientation decoding of the two items in memory following the onset of the WM array of the incidental cue, we will take the mean decoding accuracy within the time-window following array onset (0–1 s) and following cue onset (1–2 s). During the WM array window, we expect significant orientation decoding for both items. We will use one sample t-tests, to test for significant decoding of each item (one-tailed, >0). During the cue window, we expect orientation decoding to be significant for the cued item. We expect orientation decoding for the uncued item to be significantly lower than the cued item. Again, we will use one sample t-tests, to test for significant decoding of each item (one-tailed, >0) and paired sample t-tests (one-tailed, cued>uncued) to test for any difference in decoding for the two items. 

For completeness, we will also test for significant decoding of each memory item and for any difference between them at each time-point (one-sample t-test, one-tailed, >0, paired samples t-test, two-tailed) using a cluster-based permutation test (10,000 permutations) to correct for multiple comparisons over time. We will use a cluster-forming and cluster significance threshold of p <.05. 

Power analyses
We have based our power analyses on a previous dataset that decodes the orientation angles of two items in WM using EEG (Experiment 1, Wolff et al., 2017)27. We have re-analysed the data using the same methods as will be used in this study. Based on these analyses, we expect the effect size for detecting a difference in orientation decoding accuracy between the cued and uncued item to be d = 0.43. Consequently, in this study, to detect an estimated effect size of 0.43 with a power of 0.8 using a paired samples t-test (one-tailed, cued > uncued), we will need a total sample size of n = 35. Power calculations were performed using G*Power29.

Preprocessing of the EEG data will be performed in Matlab using the Fieldtrip toolbox26. The ERPs are re-referenced offline to the mean of the right and left mastoid and down-sampled to 500 Hz. We will apply a high-pass filter of 0.1 Hz and a low-pass filter of 40 Hz to all channels.  The data will be epoched around the onset of the WM array (-1 to 4 seconds). We will perform ICA to remove any heartbeat artefacts and/or artefacts due to eye-blinks. Artefact rejection will be performed separately for the time-window following WM array onset (0-1 s) and the cue onset (1-2.5 s). We will mark epochs with a high degree of variance using the Fieldtrip summary plot for visual artefact rejection and further mark epochs that exceed a cut-off threshold of 50 of the z-transformed value of the pre-processed data to detect any large artefacts due to muscle movements. We will further exclude epochs with saccades identified from the eye-tracking data. In case eye-tracking data is missing, we will visually inspect EOGs to reject saccade epochs.

We will exclude participants with fewer than 80% of epochs remaining following artefact rejection from further analyses. We expect to reject about 5% of trials on average per participant, based on the experiment used for computing our power analyses27.

Time frequency decomposition and alpha lateralization
To test whether a centrally presented, non-predictive colour cue draws spatial attention to the original position of the cued item, we will compute the alpha lateralization index relative to the cued item in the time window after incidental cue onset (1.2–1.8 s; to avoid carry over from probe onset). Spectral decomposition of the data will be performed in Matlab with the FieldTrip toolbox26. We will apply Hanning tapers with a time window width of five cycles per frequency, with frequencies of interest between 8 Hz and 14 Hz in steps of 1 Hz. We will log-transform the power at each frequency (10*log10) and calculate the mean power over contralateral and ipsilateral posterior channels (P8/7, P6/5, P4/3, PO8/7, PO4/3, O2/1) relative to the cued and uncued item. To get a lateralization index we will take the difference between contralateral and ipsilateral alpha power averaged over the specified time-window and test for significant lateralization using a one-sample t-test (one-tailed, >0).

Gaze bias analysis
A recent study has shown that human gaze may be biased toward attended spatial locations in WM17. Here, we will similarly use gaze bias as an index of spatial attention towards the original position of the cued item. If spatial attention is drawn to the original position of the incidentally cued item, we expect horizontal gaze position to be biased toward the left (i.e. negative values) for left cue trials and toward the right (i.e. positive values) for right cue trials. First, we will centre the data to the mean position during fixation (300–100 ms before stimulus onset). We will then normalize the data according to the eccentricity of the memory items, so +/-100% corresponds to the eyes being focused on the original position of the memory items (e.g. 6 dva) and 0% corresponds to fixation. We will plot the horizontal gaze position following incidental cue onset separately for left and right cue trials. To obtain an aggregate measure of ‘towardness’17, we will take the mean gaze position for right cue trials minus the mean gaze position for left cue trials, divided by two, averaged across the time-window following incidental cue onset (1.2–1.8). We will test for significant gaze bias toward the cued item (i.e. ‘towardness’) using a one-sample t-test (one-tailed, >0). 

Orientation decoding
To test whether the patterns of activity in the EEG channels contain information about the orientation angles of the items in memory, we will use Mahalanobis distance to calculate the trial-wise distances between the multidimensional activity at each time point for each of the 160 possible orientation angles in memory, grouped into 16 angle bins distributed around a 180 degree angle space. The left and right memory items will be decoded separately and independently for each participant. As in Wolff et al. (2017), we will perform the analyses on the 17 posterior channels (P7, P5, P3, P1, Pz, P2, P4, P6, P8, PO7, PO3, POz, PO4, PO8, O1, Oz and O2). 

The decoding procedure will follow an 8-fold cross-validation approach to calculate the decoding accuracy of the orientation of interest for each trial. The activity pattern of the trials of the testing fold at a particular time-point will be compared to the trials of k-1 training folds. The trials of the training folds are averaged into 16 orientation bins relative to the test trial orientation, each bin containing trials with orientations within a range of 11.25° (variable bins, see below). As we expect to exclude trials due to artefacts, we will ensure equal trial-numbers in each bin by random subsampling. We will compute the pairwise Mahalanobis distances between the test trials and each of the orientation bins using the covariance matrix estimated from trials in the k-1 training folds, using a shrinkage estimator28. To obtain a visual representation of a tuning curve, the 16 distances will be ordered as a function of orientation difference, mean-centered, and sign-reversed, so higher values represent greater similarity between the test trial and the training set. This will be repeated for all train and test fold combinations. To obtain reliable estimates, the above procedure will be repeated 100 times (with random folds each time), separately for two orientation spaces (bin centres: 5.625° to 174.015° and 11.25° to 180°, each in steps of 11.25°), and averaged across the resulting 200 samples for each of the 16 Mahalanobis distance values at each time-point.

Finally, to obtain a summary measure of decoding accuracy, we will compute the cosine-weighted means of the tuning curves12,27, and compute the mean of the resulting 16 values. Higher values will reflect greater orientation tuning and thereby greater decoding accuracy for that trial. We will take the mean over trials, resulting in a single decoding value for each time-point for each participant.

To test for significant orientation decoding of the two items in memory following the onset of the WM array of the incidental cue, we will take the mean decoding accuracy within the time-window following array onset (0–1 s) and following cue onset (1–2 s). During the WM array window, we expect significant orientation decoding for both items. We will use one sample t-tests, to test for significant decoding of each item (one-tailed, >0). During the cue window, we expect orientation decoding to be significant for the cued item. We expect orientation decoding for the uncued item to be significantly lower than the cued item. Again, we will use one sample t-tests, to test for significant decoding of each item (one-tailed, >0) and paired sample t-tests (one-tailed, cued>uncued) to test for any difference in decoding for the two items. 

For completeness, we will also test for significant decoding of each memory item and for any difference between them at each time-point (one-sample t-test, one-tailed, >0, paired samples t-test, two-tailed) using a cluster-based permutation test (10,000 permutations) to correct for multiple comparisons over time. We will use a cluster-forming and cluster significance threshold of p <.05. 

Power analyses
We have based our power analyses on a previous dataset that decodes the orientation angles of two items in WM using EEG (Experiment 1, Wolff et al., 2017)27. We have re-analysed the data using the same methods as will be used in this study. Based on these analyses, we expect the effect size for detecting a difference in orientation decoding accuracy between the cued and uncued item to be d = 0.43. Consequently, in this study, to detect an estimated effect size of 0.43 with a power of 0.8 using a paired samples t-test (one-tailed, cued > uncued), we will need a total sample size of n = 35. Power calculations were performed using G*Power29.

We will measure global meaning using the MLQ (Steger, Frazier, Oishi & Kaller, 2006), and the facets of meaning using (George & Park, 2016). We’ll measure self-esteem using a single face-valid item, and life satisfaction via (Diener et al., 1985). We’ll measure positive and negative affect using face valid items. 
We have constructed a number of items to measure meaning-making, coping, the relevance of, and surprise at the spread of coronavirus, and attitudes towards immigration (all provided below). 

We will measure just world beliefs, RWA, ethnocentrism, death anxiety, fear of a dangerous world using validated measures (e.g., Dalbert, belief in a just world; Mavor, Louis, Sibley, & Wilson 2010; Neuliep & McCroskey, 1997; Tomas-sabado et al., 2006).

conditions.value: This is a correlational study with no conditions.

hypothesis.value:
We are studying reactions to the outbreak of COVID-19. We have a number of hypotheses that we will test. The greater anxiety people feel, the more time they spend thinking about/consuming information relating to coronavirus, the lower their well-being. We expect this relationship to differ as a function of ideology- for people high on RWA, the toll of coronavirus will have less of a negative impact on well-being (particularly meaning in life). We also expect people high on RWA, conservatism, and Trump support will be less anxious about coronavirus, find the actions taken (e.g., closing schools/businesses) to be more of an overreaction, and to take fewer health precautions (e.g., hand-washing, social distancing, etc). People high on RWA, conservatism, and Trump support will also favor coronavirus information coming from Trump and Fox News, rather than other news outlets, the CDC, and science. These groups of people will also show enhanced prejudice towards minoritized outgroups associated with coronavirus, including people who are Asian, and immigrants, but not towards non-minoritized outgroups, such as Italians. 

We also expect to observe within person and normative changes in RWA and well-being over time. As the threat of coronavirus grows larger, people should increase on RWA, and their relative preference for security over freedom. We also expect to observe such increases on ethnocentrism, negative attitudes towards immigration, and prejudice. Generally speaking, meaning in life will also decrease over time. However, we expect this decrease to be weaker among people higher on RWA. We will also test whether changes in MIL precede or result from changes in RWA. Both possibilities are conceptually plausible. 

We expect for all of the above predictions about RWA and MIL, that the significance facet of meaning in life will be more relevant than the purpose or coherence facets.

attributes.title: Disinformation sharing
attributes.description: This study investigates why users share/liken/comment false messages on social media and how these user reactions (likes, shares, comments) are moderated by the recipient's attitudes and personality traits. To this end, the study participants are shown social media posts specially formulated for this study. The participants are then asked about their probability and motivation to interact with the post, as well as the emotions they feel.

q3.value: This study investigates why users share/like/comment on social media posts containing disinformation and how user reactions (likes, shares, comments) are moderated by the attitudes and personality traits of the recipients. To test this, the study participants are shown Facebook posts specially created for this study. The participants are then asked about their probability and motivation to interact with the post, as well as the emotions they feel.

q4.value:
H1: The higher the attitudinal congruence, the higher the willingness to disseminate online disinformation. (Attitudinal congruence/Confirmation Bias)
H2a: The popularity of the post moderates the relationship between the attitudinal congruence and the willingness to share online disinformation. (Chen, 2018; Matthes et al., 2012 → Spiral of silence online)
H2b: The presumption that the post will go viral moderates the relationship between the attitudinal congruence and the willingness to share online disinformation. (Chen, 2018; Matthes et al., 2012 → Spiral of silence online) (Moderation)
H4a: Online disinformation in a populist style is disseminated more often than online disinformation in neutral style. (Trilling et al., 2017 → Shareworthiness)
H4b: Online disinformation in a populist style is agreed more often than online disinformation in neutral style. (Trilling et al., 2017 → Shareworthiness)
H5: Online disinformation in populist style triggers more (negative) emotions than online disinformation in neutral style. (Wirz, 2018; Hatfield, Cacioppo & Rapson, 1993 → Emotional Contagion)
H6a: The stronger participants experience an emotion, the more they are willing to disseminate online disinformation. (Wirz, 2018 → Persuasion and emotion)
H6b: The stronger participants experience an emotion, the more they will agree with online disinformation. (Wirz, 2018 → Persuasion and emotion)
H7a: The dissemination of online disinformation is moderated by narcissism.
(Petersen, Osmundsen, & Arceneaux, 2018)
H7b: Participants with a psychopathic personality are more likely to disseminate online disinformation. More specific: The dissemination of online disinformation is moderated by psychopathy. 
(Buckels, Trapnell & Paulhus, 2014 → Trolling) 
H8: The dissemination of online disinformation is moderated by the social media activity. (Nelson & Taneja, 2018 → Availability of fake news sources)
H9: The lower the participants’ trust in traditional media, the higher the likeliness to disseminate online disinformation. 
(Miller, J. M., Saunders, K. L., & Farhart, C. E. (2016); Lazer, D. M., Baum, M. A., Benkler, Y., Berinsky, A. J., Greenhill, K. M., Menczer, F., ... & Schudson, M. (2018). 
H10a: The higher the perceived exposure to disinformation, the less likely individuals are to disseminate online disinformation. More specific: The interaction with the stimuli is moderated by the perceived exposure to disinformation.
H10b: This effect is stronger when participants think that the traditional media is the source of disinformation. 
(Wasserman, H., & Madrid-Morales, D. (2019)
H11a: The lower the participants’ trust in traditional media, the more concerned they are about disinformation. (Nielsen, R. & Graves, L., 2017)
H11b: The lower the participants’ trust in politicians, the more concerned they are about disinformation. (Nielsen, R. & Graves, L., 2017)

The outcome variables are willingness to like, share, and comment on social media posts. We measure this by asking participants "How would you normally react to this social media post?" with items "like the post", "share/retweet the post", "leave a comment" (scale from 1=very unlikely to 7=very likely). 

Moreover, we ask...

 Emotions: "How do you feel when reading this post? This social media post makes me…" with items angry, happy, amused, sad, worried, afraid, neutral, I had no emotions while reading the post (scale 1=completely disagree to 7=completely agree). 

Support: "To what extent do you agree with the message of the post?" (scale 1=completely disagree to 7=completely agree). 

Perceived virality: "How likely is it that this post will go viral?" (scale 1=very unlikely to 7=very likely)

Predictors include: 
descriptives (gender, age, education, employment, living, perceived income situation), issue salience, issue attitudes (immigration, climate, health), news use, trust in news, trust in actors, trust in democracy, trust in government, social media use, perceived opinion environment, source of information for politics, political actors followed on Facebook/Twitter, personality traits, general political interest, political knowledge, political orientation, perceived exposure to disinformation, concern about disinformation
We will use means to build indices.

q3.value:
Social science researchers have explored the relation between political ideology and prejudice, with a focus on the predictive power of right-wing ideologies. Two ideological traits – right-wing authoritarianism (RWA) (Altemeyer, 1981) and social dominance orientation (SDO) – have been considered to be particularly strong predictors of prejudice. 
The proposed research seeks to adapt Altemeyer’s (1996) RWA scale for a modern UK audience and address the conflation of right-wing authoritarianism with religiosity. Achieving this goal will improve its validity – and thus its utility – for prejudice researchers working with UK samples.

q4.value:
Study 1 - 
 Hypothesis 1 - The new RWA scale will show a weak postive correlation with SDO (e.g., Duckitt & Sibley, 2010)
 Hypothesis 2 - The new RWA scale will show a weak-moderate negative correlation with Openness (e.g., Duckitt & Sibley, 2010)
 Hypothesis 3 - The new RWA scale will show a negative correlation with feelings towards "Deviant Groups" (Duckitt & Sibley, 2010; Whitley, 1999)
 Hypothesis 4 - The new RWA scale will show no correlation with religiosity
 Hypothesis 5 - The new RWA scale will show no correlation with Social Desirability 

Study 2 - 
Hypothesis 1 - It is predicted that the relation between RWA and attitudes towards dangerous and deviant outgroups (cf. Duckitt & Sibley 2007) will be stronger in condition 2 (vs. condition 1)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Study 1 - correlational study, using; the new RWA scale (adapted from Altmeyer, 1996), SDO scale (Pratto et al., 1994), Openness scale (Costa & McRae, 1985), Feelings Thermometer (for deviant groups, Converse et al., 1980), Religiosity (Huber & Huber, 2012), and Social Desirability (Marlowe Crowne)

Study 2 - Between subjects 1 factor (correlation between Scale and attitudes towards dangerous and deviant groups) and 2 levels (Original RWA by Altmeyer (1996), and modified RWA).

q9.value: UK participants, who will take part online, will be randomly allocated to either complete the existing (Altemeyer, 1996) (condition 1) or modified (condition 2) RWA scale.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data for the first 9 participants have been reviewed, the purpose of these 9 participants was to test the functionality of the survey platforms automated point crediting system. Data were not analysed.

question.value: Participants will be recruited via three methods: 1) School of Psychology ‘participation points’ scheme; 2) volunteers recruited through social media (i.e., Facebook, twitter); 3) volunteers recruited through websites where individuals choose to take part in psychological research for recreational and educational purposes (e.g., Social Psychology on the Net; Reddit, r/samplesize). Participants in the latter two recruitment streams will self-select by clicking a link posted by the research team. From this point on, all participants will have an identical experience of the procedure.

q14.value: Consistent with Nunnally’s (1967) recommendation, we will recruit 10 participants per item based on the length of the longest scale, for each study, plus 20% for attrition.

question.value:
All response scales are from 1-Strongly Disagree to 7-Strongly Agree. Items in italics are reverse-coded, such that higher scores on a scale indicate higher levels of the construct. Variable names follow each variable, in parentheses.

See appendix A for list of scales.
Everything will be mean except Marlowe Crowne which is the sum (1 point for a socially desirable response, 0 for a non-desirable response).

Study 1 - The new RWA scale will be tested for convergent validity through consideration of patterns of simple correlation.

Study 2 - This hypothesis will be tested by means of Preacher’s (2002) method of utilizing Fisher’s r-to-z transformation and comparing the coefficients via Cohen and Cohen’s (1983) formula 2.8.5. This provides a significance test of the null-hypothesis that the difference between correlations does not differ from zero.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria

attributes.title: Causal Effects of Contemplative Practices on Affective Polarization

q1.value: Causal Effects of Contemplative Practices on Affective Polarization

q3.value:
Across the world, affective polarization towards those with different political beliefs is rife. In particular, the division between Democrats and Republicans in the U.S. is incredibly acrimonious and damaging for American society as a whole. Researchers have not found an effective intervention that can easily be introduced on a large scale to reduce affective polarization, but there have recently been attempts to investigate the effect of contemplative practices.

Petersen & Mitkidis (2019) did not find support for the hypothesis that a brief mindfulness intervention reduces political intolerance, but a brief befriending intervention is likely to have an observable effect on intergroup attitudes and emotions since compassion-based programs have a greater impact on compassionate skills (e.g. identification with all humanity and empathic concern) than mindfulness-based programs (Brito-Pons 2018).

The aim of this project is to assess whether brief contemplative practice interventions can reduce affective polarization between Democrats and Republicans in the U.S.

q4.value:
H1: Trait compassion (but not trait mindfulness) will negatively correlate with baseline affective polarization scores.

H2: Participants in the befriending condition will have a greater reduction in affective polarization than participants in the mindfulness and control conditions.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: To test whether contemplative practices cause changes in affective polarization, we will utilize a longitudinal design to test whether mindfulness-based and compassion-based practices reduce affective polarization, relative to baseline scores measured one week earlier. The study will be conducted with U.S. participants who affiliate with either the Democratic Party or the Republican Party. We will ask online participants to indicate their political party affiliation, how strongly they identify with that party, and will assess their levels of affective polarization (time one). One week later, participants will be asked to listen to either a 10-minute mindfulness meditation audio recording, a 10-minute befriending meditation recording, or a 10-minute audio recording of an expert talking about mindfulness meditation (this will be the control condition). We will therefore have a mixed design, with 3 between-subjects factors (contemplative practice condition: befriending, mindfulness, control) and 2 within-subjects factors (time: pre-intervention, post-intervention).

q9.value: We will use randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three equally sized, predetermined conditions. The randomization will be performed using the block randomization feature in Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Prolific Academic (https://app.prolific.co). Participants will be paid £1 for participating in the first session (time one) and £3 for participating in the second session. Participants must be at least 18 years old, US nationals, and affiliated with either the Democratic Party or Republican Party.

q13.value: We aim to recruit 243 participants after dropouts and exclusions, with 81 participants per condition, in order to have sufficient power to detect a small effect. We will therefore attempt to recruit 450 participants in total at time one, with 150 participants per condition, assuming that not all will complete the second part of the study.

q14.value: Sample size was determined using a power analysis (G*Power Version 3.1.9.2; Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). A sample size of 243 participants would achieve 80% power to detect an effect size f of 0.10 (partial η2 = .01) with an alpha of .05.

question.value: We will manipulate the contemplative practice condition to which the participants are assigned. The three levels of this categorical variable are: mindfulness, befriending, and control. In the control condition, the participants will listen to an educational talk about meditation.

Demographic information: Age, gender, education, asthma, meditation experience and first language.

Compassion Santa Clara Brief Compassion Scale (SCBCS) (Hwang, Plante, & Lackey, 2008)

Mindfulness Cognitive and Affective Mindfulness Scale – revised (CAMS-R) (Feldman, Hayes, Kumar, Greeson, & Laurenceau, 2007)

The feeling thermometer (Lelkes & Westwood, 2017)

Political party affiliation (Democrat/Republican/Independent/Other)
Political Party Identity (Druckman & Levendusky, 2019)

Trait ratings of the voters (Iyengar, Sood, & Lelkes, 2012)

Trust measure (Levendusky, 2013). 

Hypothetical helping behaviour (Levine, Prosser, Evans & Reicher, 2005)

The dependent variable will be a composite measure of affective polarization comprised of scores on the feeling thermometer, the trait ratings, and the trust measure. The feeling thermometer measure asks respondents to rate how cold or warm they feel toward Democratic Party voters and Republican Party voters (from 0 = ‘Cold’ to 100 = ‘Warm’). The trait rating measure asks respondents to rate how well positive traits, such as intelligence, honesty and generosity, and negative traits such as, hypocrisy, selfishness and meanness, describe voters from the two parties (from 1 = ‘Not at all’ to 5 = ‘Extremely well’). The trust measure asks respondents how much of the time they think they can trust Democratic Party voters and Republican Party voters to do what is right for the country (from 1 = ‘Never’ to 5 = ‘Always’). We will take the mean of the three measures above to create a single (composite) measure of affective polarization. 

We will take the mean of the Political Party Identification measures to create a composite score of party identification.

H1: We will examine bivariate (Pearson) correlations between baseline affective polarization, trait mindfulness, and trait compassion. We will then examine the partial correlation between baseline affective polarization and trait mindfulness, controlling for trait compassion, and the partial correlation between baseline affective polarization and trait compassion, controlling for trait mindfulness.

H2: To formally test for differences between the three between-subjects conditions, the composite measure of affective polarization will be entered as the dependent variable into a 3 (condition: befriending, mindfulness, control) x 2 (time: pre-intervention, post-intervention) repeated-measures ANOVA, controlling for age, gender, education and language. We will examine pairwise comparisons for any significant effects.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc tests suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. We will report the results of all tests conducted.

q22.value: We will include attention checks after the intervention. Specifically, we will ask participants what they were instructed to do during the audio clip (e.g. focus on sounds and thoughts, recite a mantra, or stretch their body). Participants who answer this question incorrectly will be excluded from data analysis. We will also use a manipulation check to ensure that the contemplative-practice interventions had the desired effects. Specifically, we will ask participants to indicate how much they ‘generated feelings of kindness and good-will toward others’ and ‘focused on the present moment’ during the recording they listened to. Data will not be excluded on the basis of the manipulation check results. Outliers will be included in the analysis. Finally, we exclude participants for inattentive responding on the questionnaires. Any participant who provides the same answer for every item on questionnaire which includes negatively coded items will be excluded from data analysis.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete session 2, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value:
We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to affective polarization scores. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, and education) and the composite affective polarization measure.

It is possible that the contemplative practices, mindfulness meditation and befriending meditation, will affect the individual measures that comprise the composite affective polarization measure (warm/cold feelings, trait ratings, and trust) to different extents. Therefore, we will examine the effect of the contemplative practice condition on the individual affective polarization measures independently by performing paired-samples t-tests (comparing scores at time one and time two).

The effect(s) of contemplative practices on affective polarization may differ depending on the participant’s previous meditation experience. For example, individuals who meditate regularly may not exhibit a change in affective polarization scores at time two, relative to baseline (time one scores). To assess whether previous meditation experience moderates the effect(s) of contemplative practices on affective polarization we will categorize individuals as either novices (never practice meditation) or meditators (practice meditation at least once per month) and examine the effects of contemplative practices on affective polarization for each group.

The effect(s) of contemplative practices on affective polarization may be moderated by the strength of party identification. For example, individuals who do not identify strongly with their favored political party may not exhibit a change in affective polarization scores at time two, relative to baseline (time one scores). To assess whether strength of party identification moderates the effect(s) of contemplative practices on affective polarization we will categorize individuals as either strong identifiers or weak identifiers by performing a median split and examine the effects of contemplative practices on affective polarization for each group.

We will assess whether the difference in hypothetical helping for Democrats and Republicans at time one correlates with baseline scores on trait compassion, mindfulness and affective polarization by performing bivariate and partial correlations. We will also examine whether there is an effect of the contemplative practice (between-subjects) condition on hypothetical helping of Democrats and Republicans.

q25.value:
References:
Brito-Pons, G., Campos, D., & Cebolla, A. (2018). Implicit or Explicit Compassion? Effects of Compassion Cultivation Training and Comparison with Mindfulness-based Stress Reduction. Mindfulness. doi:10.1007/s12671-018-0898-z
Faul, F., Erdfelder, E., Lang, A., & Buchner, A. (2007). G*Power 3: A flexible statistical power analysis program for the social, behavioral, and biomedical sciences. Behavior Research Methods, 39(2), 175-191. doi:10.3758/bf03193146
Lelkes, Y., & Westwood, S. (2017). The Limits of Partisan Prejudice. Journal of Politics, 79(2), 485–501. doi:10.1086/688223
Levendusky, M. (2013). How Partisan Media Polarize America. Chicago, Ill: University of Chicago Press.
Petersen, M., & Mitkidis, P. (2019, October 20). A Sober Second Thought? A Pre-Registered Experiment on the Effects of Mindfulness Meditation on Political Tolerance. doi:10.31234/osf.io/ksy37
Druckman, J. N., & Levendusky, M. S. (2019). What do we measure when we measure affective polarization?. Public Opinion Quarterly, 83(1), 114-122.
Levine, M., Prosser, A., Evans, D., & Reicher, S. (2005). Identity and emergency intervention: How social group membership and inclusiveness of group boundaries shape helping behavior. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 31(4), 443-453.

registration_responses.q1: Causal Effects of Contemplative Practices on Affective Polarization
registration_responses.q3:
Across the world, affective polarization towards those with different political beliefs is rife. In particular, the division between Democrats and Republicans in the U.S. is incredibly acrimonious and damaging for American society as a whole. Researchers have not found an effective intervention that can easily be introduced on a large scale to reduce affective polarization, but there have recently been attempts to investigate the effect of contemplative practices.

Petersen & Mitkidis (2019) did not find support for the hypothesis that a brief mindfulness intervention reduces political intolerance, but a brief befriending intervention is likely to have an observable effect on intergroup attitudes and emotions since compassion-based programs have a greater impact on compassionate skills (e.g. identification with all humanity and empathic concern) than mindfulness-based programs (Brito-Pons 2018).

The aim of this project is to assess whether brief contemplative practice interventions can reduce affective polarization between Democrats and Republicans in the U.S.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: Trait compassion (but not trait mindfulness) will negatively correlate with baseline affective polarization scores.

H2: Participants in the befriending condition will have a greater reduction in affective polarization than participants in the mindfulness and control conditions.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
registration_responses.q9: We will use randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three equally sized, predetermined conditions. The randomization will be performed using the block randomization feature in Qualtrics.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We aim to recruit 243 participants after dropouts and exclusions, with 81 participants per condition, in order to have sufficient power to detect a small effect. We will therefore attempt to recruit 450 participants in total at time one, with 150 participants per condition, assuming that not all will complete the second part of the study.
registration_responses.q14: Sample size was determined using a power analysis (G*Power Version 3.1.9.2; Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). A sample size of 243 participants would achieve 80% power to detect an effect size f of 0.10 (partial η2 = .01) with an alpha of .05.
registration_responses.q21: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc tests suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. We will report the results of all tests conducted.
registration_responses.q22: We will include attention checks after the intervention. Specifically, we will ask participants what they were instructed to do during the audio clip (e.g. focus on sounds and thoughts, recite a mantra, or stretch their body). Participants who answer this question incorrectly will be excluded from data analysis. We will also use a manipulation check to ensure that the contemplative-practice interventions had the desired effects. Specifically, we will ask participants to indicate how much they ‘generated feelings of kindness and good-will toward others’ and ‘focused on the present moment’ during the recording they listened to. Data will not be excluded on the basis of the manipulation check results. Outliers will be included in the analysis. Finally, we exclude participants for inattentive responding on the questionnaires. Any participant who provides the same answer for every item on questionnaire which includes negatively coded items will be excluded from data analysis.
registration_responses.q23: If a subject does not complete session 2, that subject will not be included in the analysis.
registration_responses.q24:
We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to affective polarization scores. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, and education) and the composite affective polarization measure.

It is possible that the contemplative practices, mindfulness meditation and befriending meditation, will affect the individual measures that comprise the composite affective polarization measure (warm/cold feelings, trait ratings, and trust) to different extents. Therefore, we will examine the effect of the contemplative practice condition on the individual affective polarization measures independently by performing paired-samples t-tests (comparing scores at time one and time two).

The effect(s) of contemplative practices on affective polarization may differ depending on the participant’s previous meditation experience. For example, individuals who meditate regularly may not exhibit a change in affective polarization scores at time two, relative to baseline (time one scores). To assess whether previous meditation experience moderates the effect(s) of contemplative practices on affective polarization we will categorize individuals as either novices (never practice meditation) or meditators (practice meditation at least once per month) and examine the effects of contemplative practices on affective polarization for each group.

The effect(s) of contemplative practices on affective polarization may be moderated by the strength of party identification. For example, individuals who do not identify strongly with their favored political party may not exhibit a change in affective polarization scores at time two, relative to baseline (time one scores). To assess whether strength of party identification moderates the effect(s) of contemplative practices on affective polarization we will categorize individuals as either strong identifiers or weak identifiers by performing a median split and examine the effects of contemplative practices on affective polarization for each group.

We will assess whether the difference in hypothetical helping for Democrats and Republicans at time one correlates with baseline scores on trait compassion, mindfulness and affective polarization by performing bivariate and partial correlations. We will also examine whether there is an effect of the contemplative practice (between-subjects) condition on hypothetical helping of Democrats and Republicans.

registration_responses.q8.question: To test whether contemplative practices cause changes in affective polarization, we will utilize a longitudinal design to test whether mindfulness-based and compassion-based practices reduce affective polarization, relative to baseline scores measured one week earlier. The study will be conducted with U.S. participants who affiliate with either the Democratic Party or the Republican Party. We will ask online participants to indicate their political party affiliation, how strongly they identify with that party, and will assess their levels of affective polarization (time one). One week later, participants will be asked to listen to either a 10-minute mindfulness meditation audio recording, a 10-minute befriending meditation recording, or a 10-minute audio recording of an expert talking about mindfulness meditation (this will be the control condition). We will therefore have a mixed design, with 3 between-subjects factors (contemplative practice condition: befriending, mindfulness, control) and 2 within-subjects factors (time: pre-intervention, post-intervention).
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited through Prolific Academic (https://app.prolific.co). Participants will be paid £1 for participating in the first session (time one) and £3 for participating in the second session. Participants must be at least 18 years old, US nationals, and affiliated with either the Democratic Party or Republican Party.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate the contemplative practice condition to which the participants are assigned. The three levels of this categorical variable are: mindfulness, befriending, and control. In the control condition, the participants will listen to an educational talk about meditation.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Demographic information: Age, gender, education, asthma, meditation experience and first language.

Compassion Santa Clara Brief Compassion Scale (SCBCS) (Hwang, Plante, & Lackey, 2008)

Mindfulness Cognitive and Affective Mindfulness Scale – revised (CAMS-R) (Feldman, Hayes, Kumar, Greeson, & Laurenceau, 2007)

The feeling thermometer (Lelkes & Westwood, 2017)

Political party affiliation (Democrat/Republican/Independent/Other)
Political Party Identity (Druckman & Levendusky, 2019)

Trust measure (Levendusky, 2013). 

Hypothetical helping behaviour (Levine, Prosser, Evans & Reicher, 2005)
registration_responses.q18.question:
The dependent variable will be a composite measure of affective polarization comprised of scores on the feeling thermometer, the trait ratings, and the trust measure. The feeling thermometer measure asks respondents to rate how cold or warm they feel toward Democratic Party voters and Republican Party voters (from 0 = ‘Cold’ to 100 = ‘Warm’). The trait rating measure asks respondents to rate how well positive traits, such as intelligence, honesty and generosity, and negative traits such as, hypocrisy, selfishness and meanness, describe voters from the two parties (from 1 = ‘Not at all’ to 5 = ‘Extremely well’). The trust measure asks respondents how much of the time they think they can trust Democratic Party voters and Republican Party voters to do what is right for the country (from 1 = ‘Never’ to 5 = ‘Always’). We will take the mean of the three measures above to create a single (composite) measure of affective polarization. 

We will take the mean of the Political Party Identification measures to create a composite score of party identification.
registration_responses.q19.question:
H1: We will examine bivariate (Pearson) correlations between baseline affective polarization, trait mindfulness, and trait compassion. We will then examine the partial correlation between baseline affective polarization and trait mindfulness, controlling for trait compassion, and the partial correlation between baseline affective polarization and trait compassion, controlling for trait mindfulness.

H2: To formally test for differences between the three between-subjects conditions, the composite measure of affective polarization will be entered as the dependent variable into a 3 (condition: befriending, mindfulness, control) x 2 (time: pre-intervention, post-intervention) repeated-measures ANOVA, controlling for age, gender, education and language. We will examine pairwise comparisons for any significant effects.

attributes.title: Wild Mango Exploration in Sumatra for Potential Health Medicine
attributes.description: These data are raw data to quantification the gallic acid and quercetin from wild mango species in Sumatra island

summary.value: The new findings in basic research on the potential of wild mangoes from the island of Sumatra as a source of antioxidant. This study aims to analyze the antioxidant profile and quantification of gallic acid and quercetin content from leaves and stem bark of Sumatran wild mangoes. Exploration and analysis of phytochemical constituents from 11 Sumatran wild mangoes. The quantitatively antioxidant activity test of wild mango with 1,1- diphenyl-2-picryl hydroxyl (DPPH), total flavonoid, and phenolic analysis, and determination of quercetin and gallic acid content by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) method.
