attributes.title: Live-Supervision
attributes.description: We examine the effect of live supervision in a standardized psychotherapy session in comparison to a condition without supervision. The study takes place in a laboratory setting with undergraduate psychology students.

q1.value: Live-Supervision in Psychotherapy Training: Study Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Trial

q3.value:
In recent years there has been an increasing interest in improving training of psychotherapy candidates using evidence-based supervision concepts (Milne, 2014). Several guidelines stress the importance of direct observation of the trainee’s competence (see for example, Borders, 2014). Besides audio- or videotape supervision, where the supervision is based on recorded therapy sessions, another approach is the so-called live supervision (LS). In LS, the supervisor observes the session of the trainee directly (e.g. via camera connection, one-way mirror) and offers immediate feedback and support, but also intervenes and corrects the procedure of the trainee if necessary (e.g. via microphone, text messages, phone-ins). 

Initial randomized controlled studies provide evidence that LS might be at least as effective as supervision as usual to improve therapeutic skills (J. L. Smith et al., 2012; Weck et al., 2016). It might be particularly effective when skills of trainees are low (Carpenter, 2012) or when trainees show reduced problem actuation (Probst et al., 2018). More qualitative study designs found that LS strengthens trust in one’s own competences (Andrews & Harris, 2017) and that therapists find the feedback from LS less frightening than from traditional supervision (Carmel et al., 2016). Despite these promising findings, most evidence so far is grounded on qualitative studies and the validity of the few quantitative studies is often limited due to a number of methodological problems (e.g. small samples, no control groups, no objective competence assessment; diverse approaches and outcomes, LS combined with other training methods, uncertainties on what was done in LS). 

Thus, further experimental studies on live supervision are needed. Therefore, we will use a randomized controlled study design to examine the effects of LS on psychology students in comparison to a no-LS condition.

q4.value:
The main objective of this trial is to test the efficacy of live-supervision in terms of improved therapeutic competencies of novice therapists. More precisely, our research questions and according hypotheses are:
1.	Is there a difference between subjects in the experimental group (EG) and those who are in the control group (CG) regarding therapeutic skills, empathy, alliance skills, self-efficacy, and anxiety? More precisely, is there a difference between subjects who receive LS (i.e. are instructed directly during a therapy session) and those who do not receive LS?
a.	Subjects with LS show significantly better psychotherapeutic skills than subjects without LS.
b.	Subjects with LS show significantly more empathy and establish better alliances than subjects without LS.
c.	Subjects with LS report significantly higher self-efficacy and less anxiety than subjects without LS.
2.	Is there a difference between subjects who receive LS and those who do not receive LS regarding the self-perceived skills? Do subjects with LS rate their own therapeutic skills higher, similar, or lower than subjects without LS?
3.	What aspects does the supervisor report back and are these aspects implemented by the subjects with LS (if yes, to what extent and when)?
4.	How do subjects evaluate repetition of practice and LS as training methods? 
a.	How useful are (a) the repetition of practice and (b) the LS from the perspectives of the subjects? 
b.	What do they learn? 
c.	What is their motivation during the experiment? 
d.	Do the tasks lead to any harm or side effects?

We do not formulate more specific hypotheses for Research Questions 2 to 4 as they are exploratory and qualitative in nature. We would like to point out that the described research questions are the main objectives of the project. In the course of the project, further research questions might arise which will then be pre-registered separately.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value:
Because of the study design, it is not possible to blind the participants, experimenters, or the supervisor. However, the SPs, raters, and data analysists will be blinded. An independent researcher will relabel the IDs of the participants as well as their group assignment in the data set. After all results will be finalized, the independent researcher will reveal the correct group identification to the authors. 

We pretested whether group allocation could be correctly identified simply by observing the therapists eye movements and communication with 10 practice videos and 7 test persons (i.e., non-/psychologists). Although the judgement was clearly by chance (i.e., kappa = -0.04), we decided to refrained from informing the final raters completely about the study design, because 2 test persons reported to have based their allocation on changes in the conversations right after participants had looked at the screen. To prevent correct or false guesses that are based on this message-communication link, the raters will be told that all participants received LS in the main assessment (i.e., they will be blind to study design).

question.value: The study is a within- and between subjects RCT, implemented as an individually randomized parallel group trial with two study groups (Live Supervision versus No Live Supervision), a baseline and a main assessment, and up to four measurement points: before baseline (t1), after baseline (t2), before the main assessment (t3), and after the main assessment (t4).

q9.value: We will use blocked randomization without extra stratification and an allocation ratio of 1:1. In addition, the presentation of symbols will be randomized in the CG using two sets of a pre-defined time schedule (e.g., to send symbols at minutes 2.30, 4.15, 5.30 etc.). Finally, video tapes will be randomly presented to the raters to reduce memory bias or halo effects which might occur when watching the same persons performance shortly after each other. An independent researcher, who is not involved in the project, programed all randomization codes with the R package randomizr (RStudio Team, 2015; Ternovski & Coppock, 2017). The concealment of the participant’s assignment will be revealed until shortly before the experiment.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
Study Setting and Recruitment
Setting. The experiment will consist of a baseline and a main measurement, which will be carried out within two hours in the video studio of the Department of Clinical Psychology and Psychotherapy. Both the therapeutic sessions of the baseline and main assessments will be recorded on video and transmitted to a screen in an adjacent room. The following persons will be involved in the experiment: One participant (“novice therapist”), one supervisor, one SP and one experimenter. In the main assessments, a specially programmed software will be used to send messages (EG) or symbols (CG) to a screen into the therapy room. The screen is positioned in such a way that only the participants can see the messages (i.e. diagonally behind the SP).  
The interview will take place either in person (Potsdam University) or by telephone. It will be audio recorded and will be transcribed afterwards.
Recruitment. The recruitment center is located at Potsdam University. Participants will be recruited via the SONA Pool of Cognitive Science Subjects of the Potsdam University, Facebook Groups, Student Council Distributors, Department Homepage, Clinical Psychology Courses and Posters at Potsdam or Berlin Universities. We will start recruitment in March 2020 and will stop it when N = 68 participants are reached, or, when the time and personnel resources are exhausted, which will probably be in the end of August 2020.

Participants and Eligibility Criteria
All participants who meet the following criteria will be included in the study or, in case of non-eligibility, they will be excluded: (a) study of psychology, (b) sufficient German skills, (c) agreement to video recording and provision of a signed consent form, (d) no license or being in training for psychotherapy, or (e) previous participation in the study.

q13.value: We will target a final sample size of N = 68 to balance the groups.

q14.value: Previous studies found large differences between training and no-training groups on average (d = 0.89, 95% CI [0.71, 1.07]; Hill & Lent, 2006). However, the typical effect size in psychological research is d = 0.40 (Brysbaert, 2019). Considering this range, we expect a moderate to almost large effect size between the study groups (i.e., d = 0.70 for the Time x Group interaction). We will pursue two analysis strategies to test the main hypotheses, that is, a linear mixed model approach and an ANCOVA approach (see “statistical analysis”). Assuming a power of 0.80 and an alpha level of 0.05, the a-priori sample analysis using the G*Power software for an ANCOVA (controlling for two variables: pre-test scores and prior helping experiences) resulted in N = 67. Using the R-package powerlmm (Magnusson, 2018; RStudio Team, 2015) for linear mixed models, the a-priori sample size resulted in N = 66, assuming a power of 0.80, an Intra-class correlation of ICC = 0.50, and a variance ratio of 0.01.

q15.value: We will start recruitment in March 2020 and will stop it when N = 68 participants are reached, or, when the time and personnel resources are exhausted, which will probably be in the end of August 2020.

question.value: We manipulated the reception of live-supervision during the simulated therapy session. The two levels of the categorical variable are "received live-supervision" (=1) or "did not receive live-supervision" (=0).

During the trial, participants will be requested to complete online surveys to assess demographics, prior therapeutic experience, and changes in the therapeutic variables. More precisely, there will be four measurement points (Table 1): before (t1) and after (t2) the first therapy session (Baseline) as well as before (t3) and after (t4) the second therapy session (Main assessment). Table 1 provides an overview on the outcome variables and time points used in the study process. We created all surveys using the software SoSci-Survey®. 

Screening for eligibility criteria. Eligibility criteria will be presented to participants for self-assessment before they make an appointment and will be checked again by the experimenter in the laboratory.

Primary outcome. The primary outcome will be the level of therapeutic competences shown in the therapy sessions (t2, t4) as judged by independent raters. 

Therapist competence. We will apply three measurements to assess therapist competence. First, the German version of the Competence Therapy Scale (Weck et al., 2010; Young & Beck, 1980) will be used, which consists of 14 items with a 7-point rating scale format: 0 = poor, 1 = barely adequate, 2 = mediocre, 3 = satisfactory, 4 = good, 5 = very good, and 6 = excellent. Two items (i.e., Item 12: Selection of appropriate strategies and Item 13: Appropriate implementation of techniques) will be excluded as they are considered to be difficult to judge given the specific task in this study. On average, Cronbach’s Alpha is good, α = 0.86, and the interrater rater reliability varies between fair to excellent, ICC = 0.42 – 0.97 (Kühne et al., 2019).
Second, a short version of the Clinical Communication Skills Scale (CCSS-S; Maaß et al., in prep.) will be applied. The original scale (CCSS; Kühne et al., in prep.) measures basic clinical communication skills with 37 items on a 4-point rating scale ranging from 1 = extremely inadequate to 4 = extremely adequate. In case any item cannot be rated, the option “not applicable” can be used. In addition, one item evaluates the overall impression of therapeutic communication on a 6-point rating scale ranging from 1 = insufficient to 6 = very good. Internal consistency is very high, α = 0.90. The CCSS-S contains 15 items and will be validated. Example items are “The therapist summarizes results (in between, at the end.” and “The therapist uses open questions to motivate the patient to talk”.
Third, following the additional item of the CCSS, four items will be presented to evaluate the overall impression of the participant’s general therapeutic skills (GTS) in communication, empathy, and ability to form a trustworthy alliance (6-point rating scale ranging from 1 = insufficient to 6 = very good; e.g.).

Secondary outcomes. The secondary outcomes contain variables based on the self-, supervisor- and SP-ratings. Therefore, depending on the perspective and the measurement point (t1-t4), the wording of the according items will be slightly adjusted. For example, while the supervisor judges the item “Think about the session you just observed. How do you evaluate the communication skills of the therapist overall?”, participants judge the item “Think about your last session. How do you evaluate your communication skills overall?”. See Table 1 for an overview of the measurement points and the different perspectives for each instrument. 
Therapist Competence. Three items of the CTS (i.e., Setting the Agenda, Discussing Homework, Response to questions and problems), the CCSS-S as well as the GTS will be chosen to capture therapist competence. 

Empathy and alliance. To examine the actual expressed empathy and therapeutic alliance in session, the German version of the Patient’s Report of the Therapy Session (PRTS; Partschefeld et al., 2013; Persons & Burns, 1985) will be applied. The 10-item questionnaire assesses the interpersonal relationship between therapist and patients focusing on warmth, trust, and empathy. The scale is 4-pointed, ranging from 1 = strongly disagree to 4 = strongly agree. Example items are “The things my therapist says and does make me feel I can trust him.“ or “He understands my words, but not the way I feel.“ Partschefeld et al. (2013) report good internal consistencies between  = .84 and  = .89 and ICCs between .82 and .85 (depending on time point and study group in their study). 

State anxiety. The short version of the Test Anxiety Inventory (Hodapp, 1991; TAI-GS; Wacker et al., 2008) is a 15-item self-report measure to examine test anxiety with the subscales emotionality (i.e., the perception of one’s own arousal; four items;  = .85; e.g., “I feel anxious”), worry (i.e., thoughts focusing task demands, failure and its consequences; five items;  = .86; e.g., “I am worried about my performance”), confidence (three items;  = .82; e.g., “I know that I can rely on myself”), and interference (i.e., irrelevant thoughts that impede with the focus on the task; three items;  = .77; e.g., “I suddenly have thoughts in my head that block me.”). A four-point rating scale will be used (1 = “do not agree at all”, 4 = “agree completely”). The authors report a satisfactory Cronbach’s alpha of   = .89 for the total score in a German sample of college students. 

State self-efficacy. The confidence subscale of the original version of the Test Anxiety Inventory (TAI-G; Hodapp, 1991) will serve as a proxy to assess therapist self-efficacy. The subscale consists of six items. The reported internal consistency is very good,  = .90. 

Usefulness of feedback on observed skills (UFOS). We developed a new scale to examine the subjective usefulness of feedback on the therapist’s demonstrated skills within observational supervision formats. The usefulness of such feedback is defined as the extent to which the supervisee thinks that the feedback induces a discernible improvement of therapeutically relevant aspects and does more good than harm. The items and subscales were derived from quantitative and qualitative literature in the field of supervision research (Alfonsson et al., 2018; Bartle-Haring et al., 2009; Bender & Dykeman, 2016; Berger, 2004; Carmel et al., 2016; Champe & Kleist, 2003; Efstation, 1990; Carol A Falender, 2014; Carol A. Falender & Shafranske, 2014; Getzelman, 2003; Gonsalvez et al., 2016; Gray et al., 2001; Hendrickson et al., 2002; Jakob et al., 2013, 2015; Kilminster et al., 2007; Ladany, 2007; Lehrman-Waterman & Ladany, 2001; Livni et al., 2012; Machuca, 2015; Palomo, 2010; Probst et al., 2018; Rizvi et al., 2016; Rousmaniere & Frederickson, 2013; Rousmaniere & Renfro-Michel, 2016; Scherl & Haley, 2000; Wark, 1995a, 1995b; Watkins, 2014; Weck et al., 2016; West & Pinsoneault, 1993; Wilson et al., 2016; Wong, 1997; Worthen, 2004; G. Zarbock et al., 2011; Gerhard Zarbock et al., 2009). We created two versions, one for live- and one for delayed feedback. The first item pool included 32 items that were further revised based on the feedback of two psychologists and two non-psychologists regarding item comprehensibility. The final versions share 22 items and contain five subscales with additional seven items being unique for live feedback. Except for two items with an open answer format, a 6-point-rating scale is used (1 = completely disagree, 6 = completely agree). Only the version for live feedback is used in this study and is described in the following.
The subscale „Improvement of therapeutic skills“ measures the extent to which the feedback (a) contributed to an improvement of therapeutic skills within the session (five items, e.g., “Due to the feedback I could improve my communication within the session.”), (b) will contribute to an improvement in the future (five items, example item: „Due to the feedback I now know how to structure the session better in future.”), or (c) contributed to insights into one’s own strength and weaknesses (two items, e.g., “I now know my strengths.”).
The subscale „Characteristics of the received feedback“ measures the quantity, type, purpose, and feasibility of the feedback. (nine items, e.g., „I found the suggestions useful.“ or “I was able to implement the suggestions.”). Two open-ended items ask for suggestions that were difficult to implement and what the supervisee would have wished for regarding the feedback.
Two items each assess the scales “Supervisory Alliance“ (e.g., „I had the impression that the supervisor treated me on equal terms.“), “Evaluation of being observed“ (i.e., wellbeing and cognitive load during the observational supervision e.g., „I felt comfortable being observed by the supervisor.“), and „Intention of use“ (i.e., intention to use an observational supervision in the future, e.g., „I would use this kind of supervision in psychotherapy training if it was available.“).

Usefulness of repetition. It is highly likely that all participants will perform better in the main assessments since they repeat the task. However, live feedback in the EG is expected to improve the skills beyond this repetition effect. To separate the LS effect from a mere repetition effect, we will ask all participants for their personal opinion on the impact of both. Thus, we took three subscales of the UFOS (i.e., 16 items) and rephrased them to stress the repetition effect: The subscales „Improvement of therapeutic skills“ (12 items, e.g., “Due to the repetition, I could improve my communication within the session.”), “Evaluation of being observed“ (two items, example item: „I felt comfortable being observed.“), and „Intention of use“ (two items, e.g.: „I would use the opportunity to repeat standardized therapy situations in psychotherapy training if it was available.“).

Adherence. The adherence to the acting script (SP) and the guidelines (Supervisor) will be examined using own adherence scales. 
Supervisor adherence will be assessed with four items on a 3-point rating scale (not adherent, partly adherent, adherent): (1) “The supervisor has provided suggestions on the agreed points (i.e., setting an agenda, discuss the homework, improve communication / relationships) and has not introduced any other interventions.”, (2) “The supervisor has given brief instructions (max. 9 words).”, (3) “The supervisor has provided concrete, behavior-related suggestions (participant should do something or say something).”, and (4) “The supervisor provided positive feedback.” Eighty percent adherence will be considered sufficient (i.e., 10 of 12 possible points).
SP adherence will be assessed with 12 items checklist that ask whether a certain behavior was or was not shown by the SP (e.g., “is unsure if therapy will do her any good”, “tries to elaborate on many topics”, “is motivated to adjust her sleep behavior and to try out new things” etc.). Eighty percent adherence will be considered sufficient (i.e., 10 of 12 possible points).
Control variables. The demographic information (i.e., age, gender, course of study, university degree, current semester) and the prior therapeutic experiences will be assessed before the first therapeutic sessions.

Therapeutic experience. We developed eight items that assess current (five items, e.g., “My friends/family seek comfort and/or advice from me for their problems.”) and prior (three items; e.g., “Within the last five years, I have completed internships in a consulting or therapeutic setting.”) therapeutic or counselling experience (rating scale: 1= never, 2= at least 1/year, 3= 2-10/year, 4 =at least 1/month, 5= at least 1/week).

Interview. The semi-structured interview consists of five deductive categories with 27 questions in total: (1) Learning results (five questions), (2) Motivational aspects that are based on Expectancy-Value Theory of Achievement Motivation (Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) and that are related to performance (i.e., self-efficacy, importance of task, intrinsic value, extrinsic value, costs; 7 questions), (3) LS or repetition as training methods (nine questions), (4) application of LS (3 questions), and (5) harms or side effects of participation (1 question). The interviews will last between 30 and 45 minutes.

Data Management and Storage
Personal data. The storage and evaluation of the study-related data is carried out according to legal provisions without the participants name or IP address. As part of the registration process, participants can voluntarily provide their telephone number or email. This information will be used to reschedule appointments only. For the experiment, participants generate an 8-numbered personal code (letters and numbers), which is linked to a study code that will be used for the questionnaires and hence, in the data set. This pseudo-anonymization (using a personal code and a study code) will be saved in a coding list, which exists on paper and only in one version. As long as the coding list exists, the study participants will be able to request the deletion of all data collected from them based on their personal code. The personal codes will be deleted after data collection. Then, all data of the study will be completely anonymous and the personal data of participants can no longer be identified. The video and audio recordings will be deleted after the independent ratings and transcriptions will be completed. The transcription will be anonymized using the study code. We will store the digital data set on secured servers at Potsdam University for at least ten years. After expiration of the retention obligation, we will delete the data set.
All outcome or dependent variables will be analyzed using sum scores (i.e., total scale scores or subscale scores).

Statistical Analyses
Preliminary analyses. All analyses will be conducted with R (RStudio Team, 2015). All outcome variables will be analyzed using sum scores (i.e., total scale scores or subscale scores).

Participants. We will present means, standard deviations (SD), and frequencies on the demographics of the total sample, by study group (i.e., EG vs. CG), and by completer status (i.e., completer versus dropouts). We do not expect any differences between the study groups due the randomization. Thus, we will not conduct significance tests (de Boer et al., 2015; Moher et al., 2010). In addition, we expect a relatively low dropout rate of about 5% (n = 4) and thus, we will not test for significance between completers and dropouts.

Rater agreement. Interrater reliability (i.e., rater judged CTS, CCSS, EAS, GTC, and SV adherence) will be analyzed based on intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs) using model 2, ICC(2, n) (Shrout & Fleiss, 1979). The mean of both ratings will be used in the subsequent analyses.
	Adherence. Descriptive statistics (in %, M, SD, Range) for SP and SV adherence will be calculated and tested for significant differences between the study groups. We do not expect any significant differences and thus, we will use equivalence testing using the TOSTER package in R (Lakens, 2017).

Reliability. Cronbach’s Alpha will be calculated to judge the internal consistencies of the measurements.

Main analyses. We will use a series of ANCOVAs and LMMs to test the main hypotheses. O’Connell et al. (2017) conclude that the ANCOVA model is the most powerful method to analyse pre-post control group designs in the case that missing data are completely at random (MCAR) or that there are no missing data. However, in case of missings at random (MAR), linear mixed models (LMM) may be superior. Consequently, we will test for the distribution of missings using the MissMech package. In case of MCAR, we will calculate ANCOVAs for those variables that are assessed twice (i.e., pre-post design; judge-based ratings). In case of MAR, we will calculate LMMs. Also, we will use LMMs for analyses including at least three measurement points (i.e., therapist-based ratings). 

Training effects. To examine the overall training effect of conducting the same therapy session twice, we will calculate one LMM using data from both measurement points of the total sample, allowing for random intercepts and controlling for PHE.

ANCOVA. We will use ANCOVAs to examine the group differences over time for those outcome measures that will be assessed twice (i.e., at baseline and main assessment; the judge-based CTS, CCSS, GTC, EAS). The scores from the main assessment (t4) will be the dependent variables, the group variable (i.e., EG = 1 vs. CG = 0) will be the independent variable and the baseline scores (t2) as well as PHE will be the control variables.

LMM. We will use LMMs to examine the group differences over time for those outcome measures that will be assessed at least three times (i.e., before (t1) and after (2) baseline and before (t3) and after (t4) main assessment; the therapist-based CCSS, GTC, EAS, TAI-GS). The study group will be at Level-2 (i.e., CG = 0, EG = 1) as will be the sum scores from the PHE, which will be grand-mean centered, to control for previous therapeutic experiences. Time will be at Level-1 (first measurement point coded = 0). At first, we will fit an unconditional model, then a model with random intercepts and finally, a random-intercepts-random-slopes model. We will compare the models regarding their model fits using 2 statistic and calculate the ICC, as well as the Pseudo-R2.

Effect sizes. We will apply Cohen’s d as the effect sizes for the time-effect (i.e., pre-post) and the Time x Group interaction. Effect sizes will be calculated according to Morris and DeShon (2002) for simple pre-post effects and Morris (2008) for pre-post control group designs. Cohen’s d will be defined as small (d < 0.50), moderate (0.50  d  0.80), or large (d > 0.80; Cohen, 1988).

Mixed-Methods Approach
To answer Research Questions 3 and 4, we will combine qualitative (i.e., qualitative content analysis) and quantitative (i.e., frequency analyses) methodologies.

Qualitative content analysis. The aim of qualitative content analysis (QCA) is to extract the manifest content of qualitative text material through categorization (Döring & Bortz, 2016). Using the MAXQDA 2020 (VERBI Software, 2019), we will apply QCA (a) to the transcripts of the interviews, and (b) to the live-supervisor’s written feedback. We will base the analyses on recommendations of Rädiker and Kuckartz (2019).

Interviews. The interviews will be audio-taped, transcribed by two undergraduate students following the “transcription rules” that are described by Kuckartz and Rädiker (2019), and anonymized afterwards. The final transcripts will be content analyzed based on an inductive-deductive procedure. The deductive categories are the interview’s main themes (research questions): (1) Learning results from the experiment (RQ: What did the participants learn?), (2) Motivational aspects, that are based on the Expectation-Value Theory of Achievement Motivation (Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) and that are related to performance, such as, self-efficacy, importance of task, intrinsic value, extrinsic value, and costs (RQ: What was their motivation during the experiment?), (3) Feedback on LS and the supervisory suggestions or feedback on repetition as training method (RQ: How did they evaluate repetition of practice and LS as training methods? How useful are both?), and (4) Harms or side effects of participation (RQ: Did the tasks lead to any harm or side effects?). The inductive approach will then be used to identify sub-categories. At first, we will conduct a within-case analysis, and afterwards, a cross-case analysis. 
The within-case analysis is sequential, which means that an interview transcript is worked through from front to back to gather an initial rough understanding of the text. Then, the rater begins the process of coding (i.e., to categorize each analysis unit with respect to the research questions), whereby the level of abstraction can vary between one sentence and a statement comprising several sentences. Each code will be recorded in a code list and will be explained by a code book (e.g., definition of codes, differentiation from similar codes, rules for the application of the codes). Once a code or a category will be created, the next eligible unit will be either subsumed in it (if it will meet the definition of the category), or a new category will be created. In addition, a case summary of each interviewee (i.e., a summary of the most important results) will be created. At first, both raters will read three transcripts to familiarize themselves with the data. Then, a preliminary coding system including sub-categories will be developed and discussed with the first author. After another three transcripts the coding system will be refined, again. 
The cross-case analysis aims to further refine the categories (e.g. to connect codes to subordinate categories). We will use the thematic analysis approach, which summarizes the themes of the research questions across all cases. 

Written Feedback. To answer research question 3, two undergraduate students will analyze the written suggestions of the supervisor. The messages will be content analyzed based on an inductive-deductive procedure. The deductive category is the type of feedback (RQ: What aspects does the supervisor report back?). The process of the QCA will be the same as for the interviews.

Quantitative content analysis. In addition to the QCA, we will also analyze frequencies of each (sub-)category per person and in the total sample. Further, independent rater will watch the videos from the LS sessions and judge the implementation of feedback by the participants (RQ: When and to what extent is the feedback implemented by the participants?) on a 4-point rating scale (0 = not implemented at all, 3 = fully implemented). The time span between message presentation and implementation will be recorded, as well.

Interrater reliability. Two raters will code the interviews and the written feedback. After the process of consensual coding for the first six interviews or feedback is finished, the second raters will code a randomly selected subsample (10%) of the original interviews (approx. n = 6) or feedback (approx. n = 3). To determine the intercoder agreement, Brennan and Prediger (1981) suggest the chance-corrected kappa coefficient that is based on the percentage agreement and the expected agreement by chance. Kappa is judged as “substantial” when ĸn ≥ 0.61 and as “almost perfect” when ĸn ≥ 0.81.

registration_responses.q1: Live-Supervision in Psychotherapy Training: Study Protocol for a Randomized Controlled Trial
registration_responses.q3:
In recent years there has been an increasing interest in improving training of psychotherapy candidates using evidence-based supervision concepts (Milne, 2014). Several guidelines stress the importance of direct observation of the trainee’s competence (see for example, Borders, 2014). Besides audio- or videotape supervision, where the supervision is based on recorded therapy sessions, another approach is the so-called live supervision (LS). In LS, the supervisor observes the session of the trainee directly (e.g. via camera connection, one-way mirror) and offers immediate feedback and support, but also intervenes and corrects the procedure of the trainee if necessary (e.g. via microphone, text messages, phone-ins). 

Initial randomized controlled studies provide evidence that LS might be at least as effective as supervision as usual to improve therapeutic skills (J. L. Smith et al., 2012; Weck et al., 2016). It might be particularly effective when skills of trainees are low (Carpenter, 2012) or when trainees show reduced problem actuation (Probst et al., 2018). More qualitative study designs found that LS strengthens trust in one’s own competences (Andrews & Harris, 2017) and that therapists find the feedback from LS less frightening than from traditional supervision (Carmel et al., 2016). Despite these promising findings, most evidence so far is grounded on qualitative studies and the validity of the few quantitative studies is often limited due to a number of methodological problems (e.g. small samples, no control groups, no objective competence assessment; diverse approaches and outcomes, LS combined with other training methods, uncertainties on what was done in LS). 

Thus, further experimental studies on live supervision are needed. Therefore, we will use a randomized controlled study design to examine the effects of LS on psychology students in comparison to a no-LS condition.
registration_responses.q4:
The main objective of this trial is to test the efficacy of live-supervision in terms of improved therapeutic competencies of novice therapists. More precisely, our research questions and according hypotheses are:
1.	Is there a difference between subjects in the experimental group (EG) and those who are in the control group (CG) regarding therapeutic skills, empathy, alliance skills, self-efficacy, and anxiety? More precisely, is there a difference between subjects who receive LS (i.e. are instructed directly during a therapy session) and those who do not receive LS?
a.	Subjects with LS show significantly better psychotherapeutic skills than subjects without LS.
b.	Subjects with LS show significantly more empathy and establish better alliances than subjects without LS.
c.	Subjects with LS report significantly higher self-efficacy and less anxiety than subjects without LS.
2.	Is there a difference between subjects who receive LS and those who do not receive LS regarding the self-perceived skills? Do subjects with LS rate their own therapeutic skills higher, similar, or lower than subjects without LS?
3.	What aspects does the supervisor report back and are these aspects implemented by the subjects with LS (if yes, to what extent and when)?
4.	How do subjects evaluate repetition of practice and LS as training methods? 
a.	How useful are (a) the repetition of practice and (b) the LS from the perspectives of the subjects? 
b.	What do they learn? 
c.	What is their motivation during the experiment? 
d.	Do the tasks lead to any harm or side effects?

We do not formulate more specific hypotheses for Research Questions 2 to 4 as they are exploratory and qualitative in nature. We would like to point out that the described research questions are the main objectives of the project. In the course of the project, further research questions might arise which will then be pre-registered separately.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
registration_responses.q7:
Because of the study design, it is not possible to blind the participants, experimenters, or the supervisor. However, the SPs, raters, and data analysists will be blinded. An independent researcher will relabel the IDs of the participants as well as their group assignment in the data set. After all results will be finalized, the independent researcher will reveal the correct group identification to the authors. 

We pretested whether group allocation could be correctly identified simply by observing the therapists eye movements and communication with 10 practice videos and 7 test persons (i.e., non-/psychologists). Although the judgement was clearly by chance (i.e., kappa = -0.04), we decided to refrained from informing the final raters completely about the study design, because 2 test persons reported to have based their allocation on changes in the conversations right after participants had looked at the screen. To prevent correct or false guesses that are based on this message-communication link, the raters will be told that all participants received LS in the main assessment (i.e., they will be blind to study design).
registration_responses.q9: We will use blocked randomization without extra stratification and an allocation ratio of 1:1. In addition, the presentation of symbols will be randomized in the CG using two sets of a pre-defined time schedule (e.g., to send symbols at minutes 2.30, 4.15, 5.30 etc.). Finally, video tapes will be randomly presented to the raters to reduce memory bias or halo effects which might occur when watching the same persons performance shortly after each other. An independent researcher, who is not involved in the project, programed all randomization codes with the R package randomizr (RStudio Team, 2015; Ternovski & Coppock, 2017). The concealment of the participant’s assignment will be revealed until shortly before the experiment.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to any human observation of the data
registration_responses.q13: We will target a final sample size of N = 68 to balance the groups.
registration_responses.q14: Previous studies found large differences between training and no-training groups on average (d = 0.89, 95% CI [0.71, 1.07]; Hill & Lent, 2006). However, the typical effect size in psychological research is d = 0.40 (Brysbaert, 2019). Considering this range, we expect a moderate to almost large effect size between the study groups (i.e., d = 0.70 for the Time x Group interaction). We will pursue two analysis strategies to test the main hypotheses, that is, a linear mixed model approach and an ANCOVA approach (see “statistical analysis”). Assuming a power of 0.80 and an alpha level of 0.05, the a-priori sample analysis using the G*Power software for an ANCOVA (controlling for two variables: pre-test scores and prior helping experiences) resulted in N = 67. Using the R-package powerlmm (Magnusson, 2018; RStudio Team, 2015) for linear mixed models, the a-priori sample size resulted in N = 66, assuming a power of 0.80, an Intra-class correlation of ICC = 0.50, and a variance ratio of 0.01.
registration_responses.q15: We will start recruitment in March 2020 and will stop it when N = 68 participants are reached, or, when the time and personnel resources are exhausted, which will probably be in the end of August 2020.

registration_responses.q8.question: The study is a within- and between subjects RCT, implemented as an individually randomized parallel group trial with two study groups (Live Supervision versus No Live Supervision), a baseline and a main assessment, and up to four measurement points: before baseline (t1), after baseline (t2), before the main assessment (t3), and after the main assessment (t4).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Study Setting and Recruitment
Setting. The experiment will consist of a baseline and a main measurement, which will be carried out within two hours in the video studio of the Department of Clinical Psychology and Psychotherapy. Both the therapeutic sessions of the baseline and main assessments will be recorded on video and transmitted to a screen in an adjacent room. The following persons will be involved in the experiment: One participant (“novice therapist”), one supervisor, one SP and one experimenter. In the main assessments, a specially programmed software will be used to send messages (EG) or symbols (CG) to a screen into the therapy room. The screen is positioned in such a way that only the participants can see the messages (i.e. diagonally behind the SP).  
The interview will take place either in person (Potsdam University) or by telephone. It will be audio recorded and will be transcribed afterwards.
Recruitment. The recruitment center is located at Potsdam University. Participants will be recruited via the SONA Pool of Cognitive Science Subjects of the Potsdam University, Facebook Groups, Student Council Distributors, Department Homepage, Clinical Psychology Courses and Posters at Potsdam or Berlin Universities. We will start recruitment in March 2020 and will stop it when N = 68 participants are reached, or, when the time and personnel resources are exhausted, which will probably be in the end of August 2020.

Participants and Eligibility Criteria
All participants who meet the following criteria will be included in the study or, in case of non-eligibility, they will be excluded: (a) study of psychology, (b) sufficient German skills, (c) agreement to video recording and provision of a signed consent form, (d) no license or being in training for psychotherapy, or (e) previous participation in the study.
registration_responses.q16.question: We manipulated the reception of live-supervision during the simulated therapy session. The two levels of the categorical variable are "received live-supervision" (=1) or "did not receive live-supervision" (=0).
registration_responses.q17.question:
During the trial, participants will be requested to complete online surveys to assess demographics, prior therapeutic experience, and changes in the therapeutic variables. More precisely, there will be four measurement points (Table 1): before (t1) and after (t2) the first therapy session (Baseline) as well as before (t3) and after (t4) the second therapy session (Main assessment). Table 1 provides an overview on the outcome variables and time points used in the study process. We created all surveys using the software SoSci-Survey®. 

Screening for eligibility criteria. Eligibility criteria will be presented to participants for self-assessment before they make an appointment and will be checked again by the experimenter in the laboratory.

Primary outcome. The primary outcome will be the level of therapeutic competences shown in the therapy sessions (t2, t4) as judged by independent raters. 

Therapist competence. We will apply three measurements to assess therapist competence. First, the German version of the Competence Therapy Scale (Weck et al., 2010; Young & Beck, 1980) will be used, which consists of 14 items with a 7-point rating scale format: 0 = poor, 1 = barely adequate, 2 = mediocre, 3 = satisfactory, 4 = good, 5 = very good, and 6 = excellent. Two items (i.e., Item 12: Selection of appropriate strategies and Item 13: Appropriate implementation of techniques) will be excluded as they are considered to be difficult to judge given the specific task in this study. On average, Cronbach’s Alpha is good, α = 0.86, and the interrater rater reliability varies between fair to excellent, ICC = 0.42 – 0.97 (Kühne et al., 2019).
Second, a short version of the Clinical Communication Skills Scale (CCSS-S; Maaß et al., in prep.) will be applied. The original scale (CCSS; Kühne et al., in prep.) measures basic clinical communication skills with 37 items on a 4-point rating scale ranging from 1 = extremely inadequate to 4 = extremely adequate. In case any item cannot be rated, the option “not applicable” can be used. In addition, one item evaluates the overall impression of therapeutic communication on a 6-point rating scale ranging from 1 = insufficient to 6 = very good. Internal consistency is very high, α = 0.90. The CCSS-S contains 15 items and will be validated. Example items are “The therapist summarizes results (in between, at the end.” and “The therapist uses open questions to motivate the patient to talk”.
Third, following the additional item of the CCSS, four items will be presented to evaluate the overall impression of the participant’s general therapeutic skills (GTS) in communication, empathy, and ability to form a trustworthy alliance (6-point rating scale ranging from 1 = insufficient to 6 = very good; e.g.).

Secondary outcomes. The secondary outcomes contain variables based on the self-, supervisor- and SP-ratings. Therefore, depending on the perspective and the measurement point (t1-t4), the wording of the according items will be slightly adjusted. For example, while the supervisor judges the item “Think about the session you just observed. How do you evaluate the communication skills of the therapist overall?”, participants judge the item “Think about your last session. How do you evaluate your communication skills overall?”. See Table 1 for an overview of the measurement points and the different perspectives for each instrument. 
Therapist Competence. Three items of the CTS (i.e., Setting the Agenda, Discussing Homework, Response to questions and problems), the CCSS-S as well as the GTS will be chosen to capture therapist competence. 

Empathy and alliance. To examine the actual expressed empathy and therapeutic alliance in session, the German version of the Patient’s Report of the Therapy Session (PRTS; Partschefeld et al., 2013; Persons & Burns, 1985) will be applied. The 10-item questionnaire assesses the interpersonal relationship between therapist and patients focusing on warmth, trust, and empathy. The scale is 4-pointed, ranging from 1 = strongly disagree to 4 = strongly agree. Example items are “The things my therapist says and does make me feel I can trust him.“ or “He understands my words, but not the way I feel.“ Partschefeld et al. (2013) report good internal consistencies between  = .84 and  = .89 and ICCs between .82 and .85 (depending on time point and study group in their study). 

State anxiety. The short version of the Test Anxiety Inventory (Hodapp, 1991; TAI-GS; Wacker et al., 2008) is a 15-item self-report measure to examine test anxiety with the subscales emotionality (i.e., the perception of one’s own arousal; four items;  = .85; e.g., “I feel anxious”), worry (i.e., thoughts focusing task demands, failure and its consequences; five items;  = .86; e.g., “I am worried about my performance”), confidence (three items;  = .82; e.g., “I know that I can rely on myself”), and interference (i.e., irrelevant thoughts that impede with the focus on the task; three items;  = .77; e.g., “I suddenly have thoughts in my head that block me.”). A four-point rating scale will be used (1 = “do not agree at all”, 4 = “agree completely”). The authors report a satisfactory Cronbach’s alpha of   = .89 for the total score in a German sample of college students. 

State self-efficacy. The confidence subscale of the original version of the Test Anxiety Inventory (TAI-G; Hodapp, 1991) will serve as a proxy to assess therapist self-efficacy. The subscale consists of six items. The reported internal consistency is very good,  = .90. 

Usefulness of feedback on observed skills (UFOS). We developed a new scale to examine the subjective usefulness of feedback on the therapist’s demonstrated skills within observational supervision formats. The usefulness of such feedback is defined as the extent to which the supervisee thinks that the feedback induces a discernible improvement of therapeutically relevant aspects and does more good than harm. The items and subscales were derived from quantitative and qualitative literature in the field of supervision research (Alfonsson et al., 2018; Bartle-Haring et al., 2009; Bender & Dykeman, 2016; Berger, 2004; Carmel et al., 2016; Champe & Kleist, 2003; Efstation, 1990; Carol A Falender, 2014; Carol A. Falender & Shafranske, 2014; Getzelman, 2003; Gonsalvez et al., 2016; Gray et al., 2001; Hendrickson et al., 2002; Jakob et al., 2013, 2015; Kilminster et al., 2007; Ladany, 2007; Lehrman-Waterman & Ladany, 2001; Livni et al., 2012; Machuca, 2015; Palomo, 2010; Probst et al., 2018; Rizvi et al., 2016; Rousmaniere & Frederickson, 2013; Rousmaniere & Renfro-Michel, 2016; Scherl & Haley, 2000; Wark, 1995a, 1995b; Watkins, 2014; Weck et al., 2016; West & Pinsoneault, 1993; Wilson et al., 2016; Wong, 1997; Worthen, 2004; G. Zarbock et al., 2011; Gerhard Zarbock et al., 2009). We created two versions, one for live- and one for delayed feedback. The first item pool included 32 items that were further revised based on the feedback of two psychologists and two non-psychologists regarding item comprehensibility. The final versions share 22 items and contain five subscales with additional seven items being unique for live feedback. Except for two items with an open answer format, a 6-point-rating scale is used (1 = completely disagree, 6 = completely agree). Only the version for live feedback is used in this study and is described in the following.
The subscale „Improvement of therapeutic skills“ measures the extent to which the feedback (a) contributed to an improvement of therapeutic skills within the session (five items, e.g., “Due to the feedback I could improve my communication within the session.”), (b) will contribute to an improvement in the future (five items, example item: „Due to the feedback I now know how to structure the session better in future.”), or (c) contributed to insights into one’s own strength and weaknesses (two items, e.g., “I now know my strengths.”).
The subscale „Characteristics of the received feedback“ measures the quantity, type, purpose, and feasibility of the feedback. (nine items, e.g., „I found the suggestions useful.“ or “I was able to implement the suggestions.”). Two open-ended items ask for suggestions that were difficult to implement and what the supervisee would have wished for regarding the feedback.
Two items each assess the scales “Supervisory Alliance“ (e.g., „I had the impression that the supervisor treated me on equal terms.“), “Evaluation of being observed“ (i.e., wellbeing and cognitive load during the observational supervision e.g., „I felt comfortable being observed by the supervisor.“), and „Intention of use“ (i.e., intention to use an observational supervision in the future, e.g., „I would use this kind of supervision in psychotherapy training if it was available.“).

Usefulness of repetition. It is highly likely that all participants will perform better in the main assessments since they repeat the task. However, live feedback in the EG is expected to improve the skills beyond this repetition effect. To separate the LS effect from a mere repetition effect, we will ask all participants for their personal opinion on the impact of both. Thus, we took three subscales of the UFOS (i.e., 16 items) and rephrased them to stress the repetition effect: The subscales „Improvement of therapeutic skills“ (12 items, e.g., “Due to the repetition, I could improve my communication within the session.”), “Evaluation of being observed“ (two items, example item: „I felt comfortable being observed.“), and „Intention of use“ (two items, e.g.: „I would use the opportunity to repeat standardized therapy situations in psychotherapy training if it was available.“).

Adherence. The adherence to the acting script (SP) and the guidelines (Supervisor) will be examined using own adherence scales. 
Supervisor adherence will be assessed with four items on a 3-point rating scale (not adherent, partly adherent, adherent): (1) “The supervisor has provided suggestions on the agreed points (i.e., setting an agenda, discuss the homework, improve communication / relationships) and has not introduced any other interventions.”, (2) “The supervisor has given brief instructions (max. 9 words).”, (3) “The supervisor has provided concrete, behavior-related suggestions (participant should do something or say something).”, and (4) “The supervisor provided positive feedback.” Eighty percent adherence will be considered sufficient (i.e., 10 of 12 possible points).
SP adherence will be assessed with 12 items checklist that ask whether a certain behavior was or was not shown by the SP (e.g., “is unsure if therapy will do her any good”, “tries to elaborate on many topics”, “is motivated to adjust her sleep behavior and to try out new things” etc.). Eighty percent adherence will be considered sufficient (i.e., 10 of 12 possible points).
Control variables. The demographic information (i.e., age, gender, course of study, university degree, current semester) and the prior therapeutic experiences will be assessed before the first therapeutic sessions.

Therapeutic experience. We developed eight items that assess current (five items, e.g., “My friends/family seek comfort and/or advice from me for their problems.”) and prior (three items; e.g., “Within the last five years, I have completed internships in a consulting or therapeutic setting.”) therapeutic or counselling experience (rating scale: 1= never, 2= at least 1/year, 3= 2-10/year, 4 =at least 1/month, 5= at least 1/week).

Interview. The semi-structured interview consists of five deductive categories with 27 questions in total: (1) Learning results (five questions), (2) Motivational aspects that are based on Expectancy-Value Theory of Achievement Motivation (Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) and that are related to performance (i.e., self-efficacy, importance of task, intrinsic value, extrinsic value, costs; 7 questions), (3) LS or repetition as training methods (nine questions), (4) application of LS (3 questions), and (5) harms or side effects of participation (1 question). The interviews will last between 30 and 45 minutes.

Data Management and Storage
Personal data. The storage and evaluation of the study-related data is carried out according to legal provisions without the participants name or IP address. As part of the registration process, participants can voluntarily provide their telephone number or email. This information will be used to reschedule appointments only. For the experiment, participants generate an 8-numbered personal code (letters and numbers), which is linked to a study code that will be used for the questionnaires and hence, in the data set. This pseudo-anonymization (using a personal code and a study code) will be saved in a coding list, which exists on paper and only in one version. As long as the coding list exists, the study participants will be able to request the deletion of all data collected from them based on their personal code. The personal codes will be deleted after data collection. Then, all data of the study will be completely anonymous and the personal data of participants can no longer be identified. The video and audio recordings will be deleted after the independent ratings and transcriptions will be completed. The transcription will be anonymized using the study code. We will store the digital data set on secured servers at Potsdam University for at least ten years. After expiration of the retention obligation, we will delete the data set.
registration_responses.q18.question: All outcome or dependent variables will be analyzed using sum scores (i.e., total scale scores or subscale scores).
registration_responses.q19.question:
Statistical Analyses
Preliminary analyses. All analyses will be conducted with R (RStudio Team, 2015). All outcome variables will be analyzed using sum scores (i.e., total scale scores or subscale scores).

Participants. We will present means, standard deviations (SD), and frequencies on the demographics of the total sample, by study group (i.e., EG vs. CG), and by completer status (i.e., completer versus dropouts). We do not expect any differences between the study groups due the randomization. Thus, we will not conduct significance tests (de Boer et al., 2015; Moher et al., 2010). In addition, we expect a relatively low dropout rate of about 5% (n = 4) and thus, we will not test for significance between completers and dropouts.

Rater agreement. Interrater reliability (i.e., rater judged CTS, CCSS, EAS, GTC, and SV adherence) will be analyzed based on intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs) using model 2, ICC(2, n) (Shrout & Fleiss, 1979). The mean of both ratings will be used in the subsequent analyses.
	Adherence. Descriptive statistics (in %, M, SD, Range) for SP and SV adherence will be calculated and tested for significant differences between the study groups. We do not expect any significant differences and thus, we will use equivalence testing using the TOSTER package in R (Lakens, 2017).

Reliability. Cronbach’s Alpha will be calculated to judge the internal consistencies of the measurements.

Main analyses. We will use a series of ANCOVAs and LMMs to test the main hypotheses. O’Connell et al. (2017) conclude that the ANCOVA model is the most powerful method to analyse pre-post control group designs in the case that missing data are completely at random (MCAR) or that there are no missing data. However, in case of missings at random (MAR), linear mixed models (LMM) may be superior. Consequently, we will test for the distribution of missings using the MissMech package. In case of MCAR, we will calculate ANCOVAs for those variables that are assessed twice (i.e., pre-post design; judge-based ratings). In case of MAR, we will calculate LMMs. Also, we will use LMMs for analyses including at least three measurement points (i.e., therapist-based ratings). 

Training effects. To examine the overall training effect of conducting the same therapy session twice, we will calculate one LMM using data from both measurement points of the total sample, allowing for random intercepts and controlling for PHE.

ANCOVA. We will use ANCOVAs to examine the group differences over time for those outcome measures that will be assessed twice (i.e., at baseline and main assessment; the judge-based CTS, CCSS, GTC, EAS). The scores from the main assessment (t4) will be the dependent variables, the group variable (i.e., EG = 1 vs. CG = 0) will be the independent variable and the baseline scores (t2) as well as PHE will be the control variables.

LMM. We will use LMMs to examine the group differences over time for those outcome measures that will be assessed at least three times (i.e., before (t1) and after (2) baseline and before (t3) and after (t4) main assessment; the therapist-based CCSS, GTC, EAS, TAI-GS). The study group will be at Level-2 (i.e., CG = 0, EG = 1) as will be the sum scores from the PHE, which will be grand-mean centered, to control for previous therapeutic experiences. Time will be at Level-1 (first measurement point coded = 0). At first, we will fit an unconditional model, then a model with random intercepts and finally, a random-intercepts-random-slopes model. We will compare the models regarding their model fits using 2 statistic and calculate the ICC, as well as the Pseudo-R2.

Effect sizes. We will apply Cohen’s d as the effect sizes for the time-effect (i.e., pre-post) and the Time x Group interaction. Effect sizes will be calculated according to Morris and DeShon (2002) for simple pre-post effects and Morris (2008) for pre-post control group designs. Cohen’s d will be defined as small (d < 0.50), moderate (0.50  d  0.80), or large (d > 0.80; Cohen, 1988).

Mixed-Methods Approach
To answer Research Questions 3 and 4, we will combine qualitative (i.e., qualitative content analysis) and quantitative (i.e., frequency analyses) methodologies.

Qualitative content analysis. The aim of qualitative content analysis (QCA) is to extract the manifest content of qualitative text material through categorization (Döring & Bortz, 2016). Using the MAXQDA 2020 (VERBI Software, 2019), we will apply QCA (a) to the transcripts of the interviews, and (b) to the live-supervisor’s written feedback. We will base the analyses on recommendations of Rädiker and Kuckartz (2019).

Interviews. The interviews will be audio-taped, transcribed by two undergraduate students following the “transcription rules” that are described by Kuckartz and Rädiker (2019), and anonymized afterwards. The final transcripts will be content analyzed based on an inductive-deductive procedure. The deductive categories are the interview’s main themes (research questions): (1) Learning results from the experiment (RQ: What did the participants learn?), (2) Motivational aspects, that are based on the Expectation-Value Theory of Achievement Motivation (Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) and that are related to performance, such as, self-efficacy, importance of task, intrinsic value, extrinsic value, and costs (RQ: What was their motivation during the experiment?), (3) Feedback on LS and the supervisory suggestions or feedback on repetition as training method (RQ: How did they evaluate repetition of practice and LS as training methods? How useful are both?), and (4) Harms or side effects of participation (RQ: Did the tasks lead to any harm or side effects?). The inductive approach will then be used to identify sub-categories. At first, we will conduct a within-case analysis, and afterwards, a cross-case analysis. 
The within-case analysis is sequential, which means that an interview transcript is worked through from front to back to gather an initial rough understanding of the text. Then, the rater begins the process of coding (i.e., to categorize each analysis unit with respect to the research questions), whereby the level of abstraction can vary between one sentence and a statement comprising several sentences. Each code will be recorded in a code list and will be explained by a code book (e.g., definition of codes, differentiation from similar codes, rules for the application of the codes). Once a code or a category will be created, the next eligible unit will be either subsumed in it (if it will meet the definition of the category), or a new category will be created. In addition, a case summary of each interviewee (i.e., a summary of the most important results) will be created. At first, both raters will read three transcripts to familiarize themselves with the data. Then, a preliminary coding system including sub-categories will be developed and discussed with the first author. After another three transcripts the coding system will be refined, again. 
The cross-case analysis aims to further refine the categories (e.g. to connect codes to subordinate categories). We will use the thematic analysis approach, which summarizes the themes of the research questions across all cases. 

Written Feedback. To answer research question 3, two undergraduate students will analyze the written suggestions of the supervisor. The messages will be content analyzed based on an inductive-deductive procedure. The deductive category is the type of feedback (RQ: What aspects does the supervisor report back?). The process of the QCA will be the same as for the interviews.

Quantitative content analysis. In addition to the QCA, we will also analyze frequencies of each (sub-)category per person and in the total sample. Further, independent rater will watch the videos from the LS sessions and judge the implementation of feedback by the participants (RQ: When and to what extent is the feedback implemented by the participants?) on a 4-point rating scale (0 = not implemented at all, 3 = fully implemented). The time span between message presentation and implementation will be recorded, as well.

Interrater reliability. Two raters will code the interviews and the written feedback. After the process of consensual coding for the first six interviews or feedback is finished, the second raters will code a randomly selected subsample (10%) of the original interviews (approx. n = 6) or feedback (approx. n = 3). To determine the intercoder agreement, Brennan and Prediger (1981) suggest the chance-corrected kappa coefficient that is based on the percentage agreement and the expected agreement by chance. Kappa is judged as “substantial” when ĸn ≥ 0.61 and as “almost perfect” when ĸn ≥ 0.81.

attributes.title: Evidence Mapping of Point-of-Care Diagnostics for Screening Coronavirus Disease 2019: A Scoping Review Protocol

q1.value: Evidence Mapping of Point-of-Care Diagnostics for Screening Coronavirus Disease 2019: A Scoping Review Protocol

q3.value: COVID 19 PCR tests were developed within two weeks of the disease identification. Although this test is currently part of the WHO’s recommended protocol for COVID 19 case confirmation (2), most resource- constrained countries have low human resource capacity for such molecular-based laboratory testing.  This has prompted the development and deployment of point-of-care (POC) diagnostics for screening COVID 19 in order to curb the spread of the disease and alleviate the health system burden. There has been a lot of media and research interest and publications on COVID 19 since its onset. However, the level of evidence on POC diagnostics for screening COVID 19 is not known. We have conducted a scoping review to systematically map evidence on the on POC diagnostics for screening COVID 19. Rapid diagnosis of COVID 19 is crucial for prevention on wards transmission and for early access to healthcare. Appropriate screening procedure can inform policy makers on about the disease prevalence and disease spots to guide implementation of targeted disease prevention interventions. It is anticipated that the results of our scoping review will help guide future research and inform health professionals in the forefront of COVID 19 prevention on currently available POC diagnostics for this condition. Our results also have potential to inform POC diagnostics policies and practices for COVID 19 and help end this global outbreak.

q4.value: The level of evidence on POC diagnostics for screening COVID 19 is not known.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: The proposed study is a scoping review, which will involve screening of titles, abstracts and full-articles. Screening will be conducted by two reviewers in parallel. One reviewer will not know the screening results of the other reviewer.

question.value:
We propose to conduct a scoping review. The review will be guided by an enhanced Arksey and O’Malley’s framework, Levac et al. 2010 recommendations and the 2015 Joanna Briggs Institute guidelines to guide the methodology of this scoping review.  Arksey and O’Malley’s stipulates the following steps for conducting a scoping review: 1) Identifying the research question; 2) Identifying relevant studies; 3) Study selection; 4) Charting the data and 5) Collating, summarizing and reporting the results.  The results of this scoping review will be reported according to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis: Extension for Scoping Review guidelines (PRISMA-ScR).

i)	Identifying the research question
The research question is: What is the evidence on point-of-care (POC) diagnostics for screening COVID 19?  
We used the Population, Concept, Context (PCC) framework to determining suitability of our research question for a scoping review study, as  recommended by the Joanna Briggs Institute 3 (Table: 1).
ii)	Identifying relevant sources of evidence
The review will include empirical literature and grey literature that presents evidence on point-of-care (POC) diagnostics for screening COVID 19. We will conduct a comprehensive search for relevant empirical literature from the following electronic databases: Google Scholar, Web of Science and PubMed. To improve the quality and reduce errors during the electronic search, the search strategies will be peer-reviewed using the PRESS 2015 Evidence-Based Checklist. Keywords that will inform our database searches will be as follows: point-of-care, screening, diagnostics, Coronavirus Disease 2019. We will search for grey literature from the following sources: humanitarian and aid organizations websites such as: the World Health Organisation (WHO); The United Nations and governmental departments’ websites. We will also search websites for updates on COVID 19 interventions. Following screening we will search reference lists of the included articles will for relevant articles that may have been missed during the initial screening. We will consult University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN) librarian for developing searches and to assist in the development of this search strategy. Additionally, we contacted authors where relevant studies are inaccessible and request articles. No language restrictions will be applied to the literature searches. 

iii)	Selection of sources of evidence and eligibility

Following database search and title screening, we will conduct abstract screening. To reduce any selection bias, abstract and full-article we will be performed by two investigators, independently. The study eligibility criteria presented below, will guide the screening process.  The eligible studies at title screening phase will be exported to an Endnote X9 library, which was created specifically for this review. All duplicates will be deleted from the Endnote library before sharing the library with the review team. Discrepancies between reviewers at the title and abstract screening stage will be resolved through discussions until a consensus is reached. Subsequently, eligible full articles will be screened by the two reviewers independently in parallel. Discrepancies between reviewers at the full article stage will be resolved by including the third reviewer. 

Eligibility criteria
We will include sources of evidence from empirical literature and grey literature that present evidence that met the following criteria.

Population
•	We will include articles presenting evidence on POC diagnostics tests 
•	We will exclude articles presenting evidence on laboratory based tests

Concept
•	We will include articles reporting evidence on COVID 19  screening
•	Articles and studies that did not include the COVID 19 screening will be excluded.
•	Articles published between November 2019 and 2020 will be considered for inclusion in this study
Context
•	Global

iv)	Charting/extraction of data
We will create a data chatting form to extract standard bibliographical information (i.e. authors, title and year of publication), geographical setting, study setting, study design and aim of the study. For each of the included studies, we will extract information on (sources of evidence), information on the target population, and type of diagnostics, sensitivity, specificity, manufacturer, approval level, key findings, most significant findings and conclusions. We will pilot the data extraction form continually updated it ensure accuracy and consistency of extracted data. 

v)	Collating, summarizing and reporting the results
We will present a narrative account of the findings from the included sources of evidence and presented these findings themes. Thematic content analysis will be employed to extract the themes, which will be critically examined in relation to the research question of our study.

We will include sources of evidence from empirical literature and grey literature that present evidence that met the following criteria.

Population
•	We will include articles presenting evidence on POC diagnostics tests 
•	We will exclude articles presenting evidence on laboratory based tests

Concept
•	We will include articles reporting evidence on COVID 19  screening
•	Articles and studies that did not include the COVID 19 screening will be excluded.
•	Articles published between November 2019 and 2020 will be considered for inclusion in this study
Context
•	Global

iv)	Charting/extraction of data
We will create a data chatting form to extract standard bibliographical information (i.e. authors, title and year of publication), geographical setting, study setting, study design and aim of the study. For each of the included studies, we will extract information on (sources of evidence), information on the target population, and type of diagnostics, sensitivity, specificity, manufacturer, approval level, key findings, most significant findings and conclusions. We will pilot the data extraction form continually updated it ensure accuracy and consistency of extracted data. 

v)	Collating, summarizing and reporting the results
We will present a narrative account of the findings from the included sources of evidence and presented these findings themes. Thematic content analysis will be employed to extract the themes, which will be critically examined in relation to the research question of our study.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will conduct a comprehensive search for relevant empirical literature from the following electronic databases: Google Scholar, Web of Science and PubMed. To improve the quality and reduce errors during the electronic search, the search strategies will be peer-reviewed using the PRESS 2015 Evidence-Based Checklist. Keywords that informed our database searches will be as follows: point-of-care, screening, diagnostics, Coronavirus Disease 2019. We will search for grey literature from the following sources: humanitarian and aid organizations websites such as: the World Health Organisation (WHO); The United Nations and governmental departments’ websites. We will also search websites for updates on COVID 19 interventions. Following screening we will search reference lists of the included articles will for relevant articles that may have been missed during the initial screening. We will consult University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN) librarian for developing searches and to assist in the development of this search strategy. Additionally, we will contact authors where relevant studies are inaccessible and request articles. No language restrictions will be applied to the literature searches.

attributes.title: Prevention of recurrent miscarriages associated with antiphospholipid syndrome: a systematic review and bayesian network meta-analysis
attributes.description: The use of the conventional obstetric antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) treatment (low-dose aspirin and LMWH) dramatically improved the obstetrical prognosis, but the presence of adverse pregnancy outcome raises the need to find other drugs to improve obstetrical outcomes. This systematic review and meta-analysis aims to provide an overall assessment on the effectiveness of all available pharmacological treatments for prevention of recurrent miscarriage associated with APS.

q1.value: Prevention of recurrent miscarriage associated with antiphospholipid syndrome: a systematic review and bayesian network meta-analysis

q2.value: Ziyi Yang, Yi Liu, Min Wang, Lin Zhou, Chuqing Zhou, Xiangli Shen

q4.value: The aim of this study is to compare and rank current avaliable pharmacological treatments for prevention of recurrent miscarriage in antiphospholipid syndrome patients.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a Bayesian Network Meta-analysis that will be performed under a random effect model.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: A systematic literature search was performed on the 15 December 2019 in the following electronic databases: PubMed, Embase, the Cochrane Library (CENTRAL), Web of Science, CNKI. We aimed to identify studies comparing an active treatment with placebo/inactive control or another active treatment in prevention of recurrent miscarriage associated with antiphospholipid syndrome. All records identified in the databases were screened by two pairs of researchers to identify eligible studies. Data were collected using a predesigned data extraction form.
Odds ratios for dichotomous outcomes (efficacy, acceptability, preterm birth, preeclampsia, intrauterine growth retardation) and standardized mean difference for continuous outcome (birth weight).

A Bayesian NMA framework was used for each end-point. The parameters of the different models were estimated using a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method. To ensure that the simulations have resulted in the convergence of the algorithm, trace plots and the Brooks-Gelman-Rubin statistic were conducted. We assessed heterogeneity and inconsistency using I² statistic and the node splitting method and estimated the ranking probabilities for all treatments of being at each possible rank for each intervention. The probabilities were summarized and reported as surface under the cumulative ranking curve (SUCRA) to provide a summary statistic for the cumulative ranking.
